In the case of a through lot, the front yard setback shall be measured from both lot lines abutting a street right-of-way. 
b.  Permit application contents, review and approval. Notwithstanding the requirements of section 18-222, the permit application shall include a statement as to the ownership of the property, the name of the non-profit association that will use the center, and the criteria for membership in the association. 
1.  A site plan, drawn to scale, shall be submitted with the permit application. The plan shall show the zoning classification, use and character of the adjoining properties, existing and proposed rights-of-way, driveways, the location and arrangement of off-street parking areas, the location of buildings and outdoor recreation areas (pool and open uncovered decks), the arrangement of signs and lighting, buffering and landscaping plans, location of solid waste containers and other features as may be required to permit an adequate evaluation of the project. 
2.  Prior to planning board review, the permit application shall be reviewed with the applicant present by a technical review committee that includes the town manager, community development director, CAMA LPO, a code enforcement officer, floodplain administrator, public works director, stormwater administrator and public utilities director. 
3.  All required local, state and federal permit and plan approvals must be obtained prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
c.  Parking. Off-street parking shall be provided so that there shall be: 
1.  One space for every 150 square feet of gross floor area under roof or floor above, including covered decks, gazebos and porches. Elevators, stairs, locked utility rooms housing electrical, plumbing and/or HVAC equipment may be excluded from the calculation of gross floor area under roof. Also, areas without insect screening below base flood elevation in the V-zone may be excluded from the calculation of gross floor area under roof. 
2.  One space for every 150 square feet of open uncovered deck and pool area, if the total area of open uncovered deck and pool is more than 25 percent but less than 40 percent of the area in 1. above. Open uncovered deck does not include walkways to the beach or to parking areas. If the total area of open uncovered deck and pool equals or is more than 40 percent of the area in 1. above, then one space for each three persons able to use such facilities at maximum capacity as determined by the occupancy rating of each. 
3.  One space for employee parking, if applicable. 
4.  Notwithstanding the requirements in 1., 2. and 3. above, a minimum of ten off-street parking spaces shall be provided. 
5.  All parking for the use of the center shall be off-street (on-site as required by section 18-148 or as provided for in section 18-145). 
6.  Off-street parking shall be screened from any adjoining land by plant material and/or fencing of adequate type, height and depth to provide a reasonable year-round sight and sound barrier. 
7.  Notwithstanding the provisions of section 18-145, remote parking areas shall be located in the overlay district and shall meet the requirements in a., c. 6., e. and f. of this section. 
7.1.  Uses currently not in compliance with these regulations will have 24 months from date of adoption to come into compliance with the regulations. 
d.  Geographical distribution. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, any property for this use shall be located no closer than 500 feet, excluding street rights-of-way, to another property for this use and no closer than 800 feet to SE 46th Street in order to prevent over-concentration of this use in a given area. 
e.  An off-street waiting area for a minimum of two cars must be provided if the parking area is gated. 
f.  Signage shall be limited to one non-illuminated sign with a six square foot maximum size. 
g.  Lighting installed on the property must comply with the provisions for town lighting in division 11 of this article and shall be installed in a manner that prevents trespass onto adjoining properties and controls glare on the public right-of-way and on public trust areas. 
h.  A buffer meeting the requirements of division 10 of this article must be installed and maintained adjacent to any property zoned or developed for residential purposes. The town may require additional buffering where needed to protect surrounding land uses. 
i.  Proposed rules and regulations that deal with the operation, maintenance and use of the property shall be submitted with the permit application for review and approval. Subsequent amendments to approved rules and regulations shall be submitted to the town manager for review and approval. 
1.  The rules and regulations shall include provisions to comply with c. 5. of this section when the number of members eligible to use the center exceeds the number of off-street parking spaces for the center. If vans, buses or shuttle services are used for compliance, the occupancy rating for the center including outdoor recreation areas shall not be exceeded. The access management plan will be a part of the conditional use permit approval. 
2.  The rules and regulations shall include a statement acknowledging that the entire beach strand in the Town of Oak Island is public property and open to the general public for recreational use. 
3.  The rules and regulations shall prohibit the center from being operated as a for-profit business. 
j.  Overnight accommodations shall be prohibited. 
k.  Additional conditions. Special conditions as provided for in section 18-224 may be required in order to safeguard the general welfare and interests of the community as a requisite to the granting of a conditional use. 
(12.4)  Condominium, mixed use. 
a.  The property shall have frontage upon a minor arterial or higher classification street. 
b.  Parking shall be calculated at a ratio of one space for every 200 square feet for each non-residential unit unless the specific uses (office, retail, etc.) are identified within the application materials in addition to the residential requirements. 
c.  A buffer meeting the requirements of division 10 of this article must be installed and maintained adjacent to any property zoned or developed for residential purposes. 
d.  Density is calculated at a total maximum of 16 units per acre, regardless of the use. 
e.  In no case shall the number of residential units exceed the number of nonresidential units in a mixed use condominium project. 
(12.5)  Condominium, non-residential. (See subsection 18-82(q)(1)) 
(12.8)  Contractor office, outside storage. 
a.  The property shall have frontage upon a minor arterial or higher classification street. 
b.  No storage or display shall be permitted within any required yard unless specifically authorized under the terms of a conditional use permit. 
c.  Storage of materials other than vehicles and machinery regularly utilized in the conduct of business shall be buffered and screened from view from roadways and adjacent properties in accordance with division 10 of this article. 
(13)  Convenience stores. 
a.  The maximum gross building area shall be 4,000 square feet. 
b.  Use must have direct access to a major arterial street. 
c.  Sufficient off-street parking to meet the facility's anticipated customer volume over the peak 15-minute period, according to a traffic volume analysis provided by the applicant. 
d.  A buffer meeting the requirements of division 10 of this article shall be installed along any property line adjoining residentially zoned or used property. The town may require additional buffering where needed to protect surrounding land uses. 
e.  Lighting installed on the property must comply with the provisions for town lighting in division 11 of this article and shall be installed in a manner that prevents trespass onto adjoining properties and controls glare on the public right-of-way and on public trust waters. 
f.  Where fuel sales are included in the use, the pumps must be set back a minimum of 20 feet from the right-of-way line and 15 feet from adjoining property lines. 
g.  Fueling facilities must meet all local, state, and federal requirements. 
(14)  Day care centers. A lot, parcel or tract of land may be used for a day care center, subject to the following conditions: 
a.  State standards. The day care center meets the standards established by the state department of human resources regarding the size of building and play area. 
b.  One principal use. No other business may be located on the property. 
c.  Neighborhood impact. There will be no adverse impact on the neighborhood as a result of traffic, noise, maintenance or other activities associated with the day care center. 
d.  Signs. Signs for the day care center shall be unlighted and limited to a total of five square feet (also subject to division 9 of this article). 
(15)  Dwellings in principal business. 
a.  Off-street parking spaces equal to one space for each residential bedroom shall be provided in addition to any other off-street parking required for the principal use. 
b.  The structure in which the residential use is located must comply with all requirements of the state building code. 
(15.5)  Electronic gaming establishments. 
a.  Hours of operation. 7:00 a.m. until 2:00 a.m.-Monday through Saturday and 12:00 noon until 2:00 a.m. on Sundays. 
b.  The maximum number of machines/terminals/computers for any electronic gaming operation business is two machines per 100 square feet of floor area excluding storage/inventory and/or bathroom/hall. 
c.  If food and beverage is served, the establishment must meet the requirements of the county health department, including any and all necessary permits and/or licenses. 
d.  The gaming establishment building must be a minimum of 300 feet from any residential zoned property. Measurements taken from the closest point of the building. 
e.  The gaming establishment must be a minimum of 1500 feet from any place of worship or religious institution/synagogue, school, daycare center or home, library, public park, recreation area. Measurements taken from the closest point of the building. 
f.  The gaming establishment must be a minimum of 150 feet between another electronic gaming establishment building/unit. Measurements taken from the closest point of the building. 
g.  No alcohol sold or allowed on premises. 
(15.6)  Farmers/Open air market. 
a.  1.5 spaces of parking per vendor must be available. 
b.  One restroom facility must be provided per every 10 vendors within a reasonable walking distance to the Farmers/Open air markets. 
c.  Vendor space will be allocated with priority being given in the following order, Oak Island vendors, Brunswick County vendors, North Carolina vendors, all others. 
(16)  Fraternal organizations. Fraternal organizations may be allowed when the site is located on a main arterial street, as defined by the town. 
(17)  Funeral homes and crematoria. 
a.  Restrictions. A mortuary may be permitted upon the finding that the use will not constitute a nuisance because of traffic and general congestion resulting from operation of the mortuary, or that the use will not adversely affect the present character or future development of the surrounding residential community. 
b.  Dimensional requirements. The parcel on which the use is located shall conform to the following minimum area and setback requirements: 
Total area 2 acres Front yard setback 30 feet Setbacks 25 feet from all other property lines  
c.  Crematoria. Whether freestanding or associated with a funeral home, crematoria shall obtain an air quality permit from the state department of environment and natural resources and shall be buffered from the public right-of-way and adjoining properties as required in division 10 of this article. 
(18)  Golf courses. All tees, greens, manicured fairways, and structures shall meet minimum setback requirements for single-family residences within the district. 
(19)  Municipal or other government facilities. Uses occupied or operated by municipal, federal, state, or county governments, unless otherwise specifically permitted as a use by right under the section 18-116, may be permitted subject to any reasonable conditions that may be imposed on the use by the town council to ensure that impacts to neighboring properties are negated or minimized to the degree practicable. 
(20)  Group homes. A lot, parcel or tract of land may be used for a group home upon the following findings: 
a.  Nuisance. The use will not constitute a nuisance owing to noise, traffic or other activities. 
b.  Compatibility. The use will not tend to adversely affect the use and development of the surrounding residential community as a result of traffic, noise, maintenance or other activities associated with the group home. 
c.  Need. The applicant demonstrates the need for the facility. 
d.  Supervision. The premises will be under the supervision of qualified personnel at all times. 
e.  Geographical distribution. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, no group home shall be located within a one-half mile radius of another such facility in order to prevent over-concentration of this use in a given area. 
(21)  Habitable accessory space. One on-premises attached dwelling unit may be permitted as a conditional use provided the following additional requirements are met: 
a.  The amount of floor area for the attached dwelling unit shall not exceed the total floor area of the principal use, or 1,600 square feet, whichever is less. 
b.  In addition to the required off-street parking spaces for the principal use, two off-street parking spaces shall be provided for the dwelling unit. 
c.  The attached dwelling unit shall be located above the ground floor or totally to the rear of the principal use as not to interrupt the commercial frontage. 
d.  The dwelling unit must meet the required setbacks of the district in which it is located and all other federal, state, and local codes. 
(22)  Handicap facilities. 
a.  Recognition of need. The need is recognized to allow provisions for handicap facilities, where deviation from the terms of this division will not be contrary to the public interest and where owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the provisions of this division will result in unnecessary hardship, provided that the spirit and intent of this division shall be observed and substantial justice done. Before any conditional use permit may be authorized, the town council shall find that the criteria set forth within this article are met and the spirit and intent of this division are not purposely contradicted. 
b.  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in subsection (22) of this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Handicap disability means a person with a mobility impairment who, as determined by a licensed physician as defined within G.S. 20-37.62 that: 
1.  Cannot walk without the assistance from a brace, cane, crutch, another person, prosthetic device, wheelchair, or other device; 
2.  Is restricted by lung disease to such an extent that the person's forced (respiratory) expiratory volume of one second, when measured by spirometry, is less than one liter, or the arterial oxygen tension is less than 60 mm/hg on room air at rest; 
3.  Uses portable oxygen; 
4.  Has a cardiac condition to the extent that the person's functional limitations are classified in severity as class III or class IV according to the standards set by the American Heart Association; 
5.  Is severely limited in their ability to walk due to an arthritic, neurological, or orthopedic condition; 
6.  Is totally blind or whose vision with glasses is so defective as to prevent the performance of ordinary activity for which eyesight is essential, as certified by a licensed ophthalmologist, optometrist, or the division of services for the blind. 
Handicap facility means any ramp, elevator, lift, or other architectural or mechanical component of a building or facility, constructed in accordance with the standards and provisions of the North Carolina State Building Code, Volume 1-C, that allows such structure to be reasonably entered, accessed and used by an individual with a handicap disability. For the purposes of this subsection (22), the terms "entered," "accessed," and "used" shall refer to the primary ingress/egress of the structure. 
Physically handicapped person means an individual who has a physical disability as determined by a licensed physician that results in a functional limitation in gaining access to and ability to reasonably use a building or facility. 
Structure means any principal building or facility, whether privately or publicly owned. 
c.  Placement of handicap facilities. The town council may grant a conditional use permit for the placement of a handicap facility in accordance with the provisions as set forth with division 8 of this article. As handicap facilities represent a necessary and unique use as defined within this section, these uses shall be given special consideration and review. In making their decision, the planning board and town council shall carefully contemplate the following criteria: 
1.  The applicant's property for which the conditional use permit is sought, because of literal enforcement of the provisions of the setback requirements, cannot reasonably or practically accommodate the installation of the necessary handicap facility. 
2.  All possible means for complying with the setbacks requirements applicable to the property in question have been thoroughly considered and exhausted by the applicant. 
3.  The proposed handicap facility has been appropriately designed so as not to injure or significantly alter the aesthetic values of the neighborhood. 
4.  The handicap facility has been designed, with regard to size and location so as to minimize encroachments upon the setback requirement. 
5.  The applicant has provided a letter from a licensed physician diagnosing the specific physical handicap afflicting the applicant. 
6.  The property for which the conditional use is sought is the applicant's primary and permanent residence. 
The conditions imposed upon an applicant for a handicap facility conditional use permit, if granted, shall seek to conform with the permitted uses and regulations of the town consolidated development ordinance. 
d.  Granting of permit. The physical handicap disability of an applicant shall not be the sole determining factor for the approval of a handicap facility conditional use permit by the town council. 
(23)  Hospitals, nursing homes and convalescent centers. 
a.  Restrictions. A lot, parcel or tract of land may be used for a convalescent home, hospital or nursing home upon the finding of the planning board that the use will not constitute a nuisance because of traffic, noise, number of patients or persons being cared for or that the use will not adversely affect the present character or future development of the surrounding residential community. 
b.  Dimensional requirements. The lot on which the building or buildings are located shall conform to the following minimum area, setback and parking requirements: 
1.  Convalescent home: 
Total area 2 acres Front yard setback 30 feet Setbacks 25 feet from property lines  
2.  Hospital: 
Total area 5 acres Setbacks 50 feet from property lines  
3.  Nursing home: 
Total area 2 acres Front yard setback 30 feet Setbacks 25 feet from all other property lines  
c.  State and local building and zoning regulations. Convalescent homes, hospitals and nursing homes must meet all state and local building and zoning regulations as presented by this division. 
(24)  Hotels, motels, and transient lodging (including accessory swimming pool for the use of guests; cocktail lounges and taverns). A motel may be established upon a finding that such use will not constitute a nuisance because of noise, sanitary conditions or traffic and will not adversely affect the present character or future development of the surrounding residential community. The project shall be subject to the following standards: 
a.  Screening. A substantial, aesthetically pleasing fence, not less than six feet high shall be constructed and maintained along the full length of any property line that lies adjacent to property used for residential purposes. 
b.  Setback. No building or structure shall be located less than 40 feet from the front property line, and no building shall be located less than 25 feet from all other property lines. All parking areas shall meet the setback requirements of the district in which the use is located. All parking shall be off-street. 
c.  Site design map. An accurate map of the property shall be provided showing the following: 
1.  Location and proposed use of all buildings and structures; 
2.  Location and total number of all parking spaces; 
3.  Location of all drives and access driveways; 
4.  For motels, the total number of guestrooms or units proposed; and 
5.  Any additional information that the planning board finds necessary. 
d.  Additional conditions. A restaurant, coffeeshop, cocktail lounge, tavern and nightclub may be maintained as accessory units attached under the same structure with a motel. Parking for such uses shall be provided in addition to the requirements of the motel. 
e.  Special conditions. Special conditions may be required in order to safeguard the general welfare and interests of the community as a requisite to the granting of a conditional use. 
(24.5)  Large dwelling, single-family. A large home greater than 3,999 square feet may be established upon a finding that such use will not constitute a nuisance because of traffic, stormwater retention, overflow parking, sewer and water system impact/capacity, and will not adversely affect the present character or future development of the surrounding residential community. The project shall be subject to the following standards: 
a.  Does not materially endanger the public health or safety. 
b.  Must comply with all the required conditions and specifications. 
c.  Will not substantially injure the value of adjoining property. 
d.  Will be in harmony with the area in which it is located and be in general conformity with the comprehensive plan. 
e.  When six or more parking spaces are required then an adequate ingress and egress area of 12 feet in width shall be required. 
f.  The site must be able to maintain the 1.5 inches of rainfall per storm event; a professionally-designed engineered report detailing the rainfall capture must be provided. 
g.  If utility infrastructure is not adequate, the owner shall install such utilities as needed at the owner's expense. 
h.  The applicant may provide documentation detailing the effects of the project on the surrounding adjacent properties' values if desired or if decision making board determines it necessary. 
i.  Provide adequate lighting that is in compliance with division 11 lighting of this article. 
j.  Provide screening for garbage and recycling containers under the house screen from the street and outside. 
k.  Water/sewer approvals must be furnished to the zoning administrator prior to the issuance of a development and/or building permit. 
l.  Side yard setbacks shall be ten feet. 
m.  Houses 4,000 of heated or cooled square feet or greater can only be built on lots greater than 13,000 square feet of buildable area. 
Editor's note- An amendment of Oct. 11, 2016, added provisions to § 18-226 pertaining to large single-family dwelling as a new subsection (25) and indicated for subsequent subsections to be renumbered sequentially. Inasmuch as a precedent for decimal designations had been previously established, and for the purpose of preserving the accuracy of existing internal Code references, said provisions have been codified as a new subsection (24.5), at the editor's discretion. 
(25)  Manufactured housing park. 
a.  The lot size for each manufactured housing unit must meet the minimum lot size requirements, setback and yard requirements of the R-6MH district. Recreational vehicles shall not be occupied in manufactured housing parks. 
b.  All manufactured homes shall have skirting around the entire perimeter. 
c.  The park shall contain at least three manufactured housing units. 
d.  Off-street parking for at least two automobiles must be provided on each lot. 
e.  Public water and sewer services shall be provided to all lots within the park. 
f.  Sanitation services shall be equivalent to the services provided by the town and the county. 
g.  All manufactured housing units must front on a public or private street. 
h.  A screening buffer as described in division 10 of this article shall be installed and maintained along all rear and side property lines of the manufactured housing park site. 
(26)  Marinas. 
a.  A site plan for the facility must be submitted and approved by the town. 
b.  Buffers must be installed on all property lines abutting residentially zoned or used property in accordance with the requirements of this division. 
c.  Lighting installed on the property must comply with the provisions for town lighting in division 11 of this article and shall be installed in a manner that prevents trespass onto adjoining properties and controls glare on the public right-of-way and on public trust waters. 
d.  One parking space for each slip plus one parking space for each four dry storage spaces shall be provided. In addition, if a public boat ramp is provided, adequate parking spaces for cars and boat trailers and adequate waiting areas for launch and recovery of boats shall be provided. 
e.  For facilities larger than ten slips or dry storage spaces, a minimum of two toilets and two lavatories shall be provided for each 40 slips or dry storage spaces, or fraction thereof. 
f.  Facilities with more than ten slips must provide approved pump out facilities. 
g.  Residence aboard any watercraft docked or stored at the facility for more than 30 days within any 90-day period is prohibited. 
h.  Marinas shall be located, designed, and operated in a manner that is compatible with surrounding land uses and does not create traffic congestion or hazards. 
(27)  Miniature golf. 
a.  Buffers must be installed on all property lines abutting residentially zoned or used property in accordance with the requirements of this division. 
b.  Lighting installed on the property must comply with the provisions for town lighting in division 11 of this article and shall be installed in a manner that prevents trespass onto adjoining properties and controls glare on the public right-of-way and on public trust waters. 
c.  Required off-street parking spaces shall be provided. 
(28)  Outdoor sales and display. 
a.  Outdoor sales and display areas, both incidental and principal uses are not to exceed one acre in size. 
b.  Lighting installed on the property must comply with the provisions for town lighting in division 11 of this article and shall be installed in a manner that prevents trespass onto adjoining properties and controls glare on the public right-of-way and on public trust waters. 
c.  Outdoor sales and displays can be a stand-alone principal use or can be intended to enhance an existing business and cannot be located in existing vehicular spaces. 
d.  No outdoor sales and displays shall be conducted as a principal use within the town without first having obtained a conditional use permit from the town. The conditional use permit must me be made available to the town upon request. 
e.  All principal use outdoor sales and display structures such as tents and sales stands will need to be reviewed for compliance with all applicable state codes and temporary outdoor sales and display that remain on site exceeding 180 days will be considered as a permanent structure and shall meet all federal, state, and local regulations. 
(29)  Parking facilities, public. 
a.  Reserved. 
b.  Reserved. 
c.  A buffer meeting the requirements of division 10 of this article shall be installed along any property line adjoining residentially zoned or used property. The town may require additional buffering where needed to protect surrounding land uses. 
d.  A vegetation preservation plan that complies with the requirements of article III of chapter 32 of this Code must be submitted with the application for a conditional use permit. 
e.  The facility must comply with local and state requirements for stormwater management. 
f.  The site plan must utilize feasible options to minimize impervious surface. 
g.  Lighting installed on the property must comply with the provisions for town lighting in division 11 of this article and shall be installed in a manner that prevents trespass onto adjoining properties and controls glare on the public right-of-way and on public trust waters. 
(30)  Places of worship. 
a.  Yard requirements. Yard requirements are the same as the requirements for the district in which the use is located, plus a requirement for two square feet of open space for each one square foot of building coverage. Areas designated for parking may be included in the open space. 
b.  Access. Ingress and egress for vehicular traffic shall be on an arterial or major collector street. 
(31)  Planned unit developments (PUD). 
a.  Planned unit developments; C-LD district (PUD-C). All forms of innovative land usage for residential developments such as single-family cluster subdivisions, townhouses, multifamily dwellings, retirement complexes, patio lots, as long as the overall density of land used for residential structure coverage ("foot print") and for amenities of perpetually ensured open space provide not more than one dwelling unit or residency room per 7,500 square feet of land. Public or community water and sewer service must be available. Accessory commercial and medical services intended primarily for residents are permissible. The intent of permitting such innovative developments is to encourage a higher quality of development than it may be possible to achieve by use of a particular tract of land for a traditional detached single-family home subdivision. In all cases, adequate external buffering shall be provided by much larger setbacks of structures and uses such as active recreational areas, swimming pools, ancillary structures, trafficways, parking, and all other use of the land than green open space. In no case shall any structure or pavement or sign be located closer than 25 feet to any property line. Adequate instruments to the benefit of all persons who buy or rent in the proposed development must be filed and are subject to the same scrutiny and judgment as the site and structural and landscape plans. The requirements of the town's subdivision regulations shall apply to all planned unit developments per section 18-415. 
b.  Planned unit development; residential districts (PUD-R). The purpose of the PUD provision is to encourage more creative and innovative design for residential development than is possible under the general district regulations. It is designed to promote efficient use of land with an economic arrangement of structures, circulation systems, land use, and utilities. The PUD provision is also intended to encourage the preservation of existing natural features and site amenities in an aesthetically pleasing manner. 
1.  All projects have a minimum site size of 25 acres of net buildable area on one or more contiguous parcels on the mainland side of Oak Island. 
2.  The residential density does not exceed the levels permitted in the district in which the PUD is located. 
3.  The development reserves a minimum of 15 percent of the total land area for open space and/or recreational areas. Area of land dedicated for public use shall be subtracted from the total land area used to calculate the required open space and commercial requirements 
4.  Placement of structures within the PUD shall be governed by the state building code. The yard requirements of the district in which the PUD is located do not apply to the internal design of the site. Yards abutting adjacent properties at the periphery of the site shall be provided in accordance with the district's requirements. 
5.  The town may require an appropriate buffer along the side and rear of the site where it abuts residentially zoned or used property. 
6.  Commercial development in PUD-R. The proposed development should have a mixture of residential and nonresidential land uses, with up to ten percent of the developed area consisting of nonresidential uses. Types of allowed commercial uses shall be approved by the town council on the site plan. Elementary schools are an important community element. Public structures, such as schools, churches and civic buildings, and public open spaces, such as squares, parks, playgrounds, and greenways should be integrated into the neighborhood pattern. 
7.  The requirements of the town's subdivision regulations shall apply to all planned unit developments per section 18-415. 
c.  PUD-M planned unit development mixed-use. 
1.  Purpose. This PUD is intended to permit development in accordance with a master plan for a tract of land into a mixed-use community. Within such development the location of all improvements shall be planned in such a manner as to permit a variety of residential and nonresidential uses in an orderly relationship to one another with an adequate provision of open space and minimal disturbance to natural features. This PUD is appropriate when the landowner contemplates a diversity of uses and/or a phased development. Flexible requirements permit the developer to approach the development as an integrated social, environmental and economic system, and to thereby be innovative in offering a greater choice of living and working environment. The allowance of nonresidential uses in the community in a manner harmonious to residential areas can be very beneficial to the residents thereof providing nearby opportunities for employment and services. 
i.  Density shall be determined by the underlying zoning classification. At least ten percent of the PUD-M shall be open space. 
ii.  The PUD-M must consist of ten contiguous acres located on the mainland. 
iii.  Placement of structures within the PUD-M shall be governed by the state building code. The yard requirements of the district in which the PUD is located do not apply to the internal design of the site. Yards abutting adjacent properties at the periphery of the site shall be provided in accordance with the district's requirements. 
iv.  The will be a minimum of ten percent residential floor area in the PUD-M. 
v.  The town may require an appropriate buffer along the side and rear of the site where it abuts residentially zoned or used property. 
vi.  The requirements of the town's subdivision regulations shall apply to all planned unit developments per section 18-415. 
vii.  Several land uses are recognized by the town as conditional uses. If approved by the town council on the site plan, the uses will be allowed in the PUD-M without a conditional use permit subject to a development review and approval process by the town's technical review committee per the conditions in sections 18-224 and 18-226. 
d.  PUD-RDP Planned unit development recreational destination park. 
1.  Purpose. The purpose of the recreational destination park (PUD-RDP) is to provide sound and healthy recreational sites located on the mainland of Oak Island in which campers are situated. Furthermore, this PUD is intended for short-term occupancy and is to be used primarily for leisure time activities at or near natural attractions. 
2.  Permitted site uses. Unless otherwise set forth herein, occupied travel trailers, pick-up coaches, motor homes, and camping trailers defined as a recreational vehicle per section 18-32 suitable for temporary habitation and used for travel, vacation, and recreation purposes shall be permitted. No permanent external appurtenances such as carports, cabanas, decks or patios may be attached to any recreational vehicle and no detached accessory buildings or uses will be allowed on any recreational vehicle site in the park. In addition, park models and cottages shall be permitted subject to the requirements of this section. Permanent external appurtenances and detached accessory buildings and uses may be allowed on park model and cottage sites. 
3.  Permitted park accessory structures and uses may include but are not limited to management headquarters, toilets, dumping stations, showers, coin operated laundry facilities, swimming pools, tennis courts, marinas, play grounds, picnic areas, fitness centers, recreational open space and other uses and structures customarily incidental to the operation of a destination park. Such accessory uses may serve adjacent development if specifically designed to do so. 
4.  All recreational vehicles must be in good repair, road worthy, and properly tagged and registered. All utility services for recreational vehicle sites shall be maintained up to current code standards. 
5.  Park models, cottages, external appurtenances and accessory buildings, and park accessory structures and uses must be kept in good repair and comply with all applicable building and fire codes to insure safety of the residents and users. 
6.  Recreational destination park rules and covenants must be approved by town council and enforced at all times by park management. The town will have access to the park to insure all rules and covenants are enforced. 
7.  Streets shall be private, and shall be constructed with a stabilized travel way (stone, paving, or other suitable material) approved by the town public works director or his designee. 
8.  Each recreational vehicle site shall contain a stabilized vehicular parking pad of stone, paving or other suitable material. No part of a travel trailer or other unit placed on a site shall be closer than 15 feet to another travel trailer or other park building. 
9.  Cottage floor area shall not exceed 1,200 square feet.
