11.  Park plan. Notwithstanding the requirements of section 18-222, the permit application shall include a park plan that meets the following requirements: 
a.  The park shall be located so that no entrance or exit from the park shall discharge traffic into any residential district nor require movement of traffic from the park through a residential district. A recreational destination park shall have a minimum of 150 feet of frontage on a public street. 
b.  Site conditions: Conditions of the soil, groundwater levels, drainage and topography shall not create hazards on the property or to the health or safety of the occupants. 
c.  Design of access to the park: Entrances and exits to a recreational destination park shall be designed for safe and convenient movement of traffic into and out of the park and to minimize marginal fraction with free movement of traffic on adjacent streets. All traffic into or out of the park shall be through such entrances and exits. No entrance or exit shall require a turn at an acute angle for vehicles moving in the direction intended, and entrances and exits are to be designed to facilitate easy turning and movements of vehicles with trailers attached. No impediment to visibility shall be created or maintained which obscures the view of an approaching driver. 
d.  Minimum setbacks for park external boundaries: 
i.  Front yard setback: 30 feet. 
ii.  Side yard setback : 20 feet. 
iii.  Rear yard setback: 20 feet. 
e.  The plat shall be drawn to scale by a registered civil engineer or land surveyor and show exact dimensions of the parcels of land under consideration. The elements to be shown are as follows: 
i.  All property dimensions, lots, and street systems, proposed location of buildings and size, plans for screening and protection of abutting properties, means of ingress, egress and circulation arrangements, open spaces and other facilities. 
ii.  The number of acres for the park, open space, and site use shall be shown and each lot shall be numbered. 
iii.  A drainage plan with two-foot vertical contour intervals. 
iv.  All utility and storm water plans must be approved by the town public works director or his designee. 
f.  The park site shall contain not less than ten acres of net buildable area. 
g.  The requirements of the town's subdivision regulations shall apply to all planned unit developments per section 18-415. 
h.  Total density shall not exceed 24 units per acre with up to 25 percent of the total density consisting of any combination of park model and cottage sites. 
12.  Signage plans shall meet the requirements of the district in which the park is located. 
13.  Lighting plans shall meet the requirements of division 11 of this article. 
14.  Vegetation plans shall meet the requirements of chapter 32-76.3 of this Code. 
(31.5)  Private clubs or lodges. 
a.  The property shall have frontage upon a collector or higher classification street. 
b.  Outdoor recreation or other service facilities shall be buffered from adjacent residentially zoned or used property in accordance with division 10 of this article. 
(32)  Public or private utility use or structure. The requirement for conditional use approval shall not apply to municipal utility uses or structures unless otherwise referenced under section 18-116 nor shall public or private utility uses or structures that are approved as part of the major subdivision review and approval process provided for in article III of this chapter be subject to the conditional use permitting process. Where subject to the conditional use approval process, such uses or structures may be established when the town council finds that: 
a.  Necessity. The proposed use at the location selected is deemed necessary for public convenience and service but cannot be supplied with equal effectiveness if located in a district where the use is permitted by right. 
b.  Community protection. The proposed location will not endanger the health and safety of workers or residents in the community and will not impair or prove detrimental to neighboring properties. All buildings shall be in character with the surrounding residences. 
c.  Aesthetics. Landscaping and/or fencing shall be provided where deemed necessary. 
d.  Transmission stations. Utility transmitting or relay stations and/or towers may be permitted, provided that no such station or tower shall be permitted on a site less than one acre in area and that no site shall have a horizontal dimension less than the height of the tower. The tower must be located a distance of 50 feet, plus its height, from all bounding lot lines or street right-of-way. 
e.  Minor structures. Minor structures, such as hydrants, relay stations, vaults, water pump stations, wastewater lift stations, telephone or lightpoles, pole transmitters or transformers, or similar equipment, shall not be subject to the regulations of subsection (32) of this section. 
f.  Transmission lines. Public utility transmission lines shall be permitted only if a right-of-way of sufficient width shall permit the safe construction and maintenance of the line and prevent any hazard to surrounding property. On a one-circuit or two-circuit transmission line, the distance from the tower base to the nearest boundary of the transmissions line right-of-way shall be no less than 25 feet. On a three-circuit or four-circuit transmission line, the distance shall be no less than 50 feet. The town council may require suitable fencing or landscaping of a tower base when, in the opinion of the council, it is necessary to protect the public or conserve the values of the surrounding property. Standard distribution lines, such as telephone, electric light and power lines carrying less than 33,000 volts and usually located along public rights-of-way are not subject to these conditions provided all new such lines are placed underground with their customary above ground appurtenances being considered minor structures in accordance with subsection e. above. 
g.  Major water/wastewater facilities. Major water or wastewater treatment facilities and elevated water tanks may be permitted as referenced under section 18-116. Where such facilities are proposed for location in a district where conditional use approval is required, the primary considerations shall be (1) the technical necessity to locate the facility at the location proposed; (2) the anticipated benefit to the public, health, safety and welfare; (3) suitability of the site for the use proposed to include soil characteristic suitability and the capability to provide adequate perimeter screening and buffering from adjacent properties; and (4) the anticipated ability to be able to acquire the necessary state permits for the proposed facilities. 
(33)  Recreational campgrounds and recreational vehicle parks. Campgrounds for recreational purposes may be located on the island, provided that: 
a.  Accessibility. The campground shall be readily accessible to a public street, and no entrance or exit from the campground shall require traffic movement through a developed residential district. Access to campsites or recreational vehicle sites shall be provided through well-maintained roadways within the campground. 
b.  Dimensions. No campground or recreational vehicle park shall be less than two acres or one city block in size. No campsite shall be located closer than twenty-five feet to the right-of-way of any public street. Gross density of the campground shall not exceed twenty-five trailer spaces per acre and no more than one vehicle or trailer parked on each site. 
c.  Site design. Detailed site plans showing the proposed type and location of campsites, access roads, location and type of all related facilities and a description of the provisions for utilities shall be provided. During the review, special attention shall be directed toward ensuring that adequate space is provided for each campsite. Concrete slabs shall be allowed as long as they do not exceed 100 square feet per campsite and shall not violate the restrictions of impervious surface coverage as provided in this section. 
d.  Walkways. Walkways shall be provided to service facilities and comfort stations. 
e.  Screening and landscaping. Additional yard areas and landscaping may be required when granting the conditional use. Campgrounds shall be enclosed by an appropriate fence except at drive-in entrance or exit. 
f.  Recreational vehicles. A recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is on wheels or a jacking system, is attached to the site only by quick-disconnect type utilities and security devices, and has no additions. Recreational vehicles placed on sites shall be on site for fewer than 180 consecutive days, and be fully licensed and ready for highway use. 
g.  Additions. All additions, except those provided by the facility owner, are prohibited. 
(34)  Retirement homes and rest homes. 
a.  If no state license is required, retirement homes and rest homes shall have a written operation or procedures manual and on-premises management or supervisory personnel. 
b.  The minimum lot area for the facility is the lot requirement for the district or 7,500 square feet in districts where no minimum lot area is established. 
c.  The facility must provide a minimum of 100 square feet of heated area for each resident. 
d.  A retirement home or rest home may not be located within 2,500 feet of another retirement home or rest home. 
e.  One off-street parking space shall be provided for every three residents, plus one space for on-site supervisors. 
(34.5)  Seafood processing, purchasing, sales. 
a.  The property shall have frontage upon a collector or higher classification street. 
b.  The use shall comply with all applicable regulations of the Brunswick County Health Department, N.C. Department of Agriculture, the Federal Food and Drug Administration and all other applicable federal, state, or local agencies. 
(35)  Schools, public and private. 
a.  Minimum site area for public schools shall meet the requirements established by the state department of public instruction. Private schools shall provide a minimum site area of 400 square feet per student for elementary, 600 square feet for middle, and 800 square feet for high school. 
b.  Private schools shall provide adequate space for outdoor recreation. 
c.  Temporary (mobile) classrooms shall be treated as a temporary use and must be approved as a modification of the conditional use permit. 
d.  Adequate off-street parking and loading/unloading area shall be provided. 
e.  Adequate buffering shall be installed between the school site and any adjoining residentially zoned or used property. 
(36)  Service station. 
a.  Service stations must comply with the provisions of section 18-82(f). 
b.  Storage of vehicles for more than 120 days is prohibited. 
c.  All outdoor space for temporary storage of vehicles must be buffered. 
d.  A buffer meeting the requirements of division 10 of this article shall be installed along any property line adjoining residentially zoned or used property. The town may require additional buffering where needed to protect surrounding land uses. 
(36.5)  Shopping centers. 
a.  The property shall have frontage upon a collector or higher classification street. 
b.  Any shopping center building shall be set back a minimum of 50 feet from any street right-of-way. For approved out parcels located around the perimeter of the center, the setbacks of the general zoning district shall apply. 
c.  Design, landscaping and signage shall be unified and shall harmonize with adjacent land uses to the degree practicable. 
d.  In addition to the requirements of section 18-222, the applicant shall provide the following preliminary master plan of the development: 
1.  A plan for traffic circulation and parking and an analysis of anticipated traffic volumes. 
2.  Plans for water and wastewater systems to be constructed in accordance with town standards and specifications. 
3.  Plans for access for fire protection including designation of fire lanes, hydrant and standpipe locations and knox-box locations. 
4.  A preliminary plan that addresses stormwater management and anticipated methods of complying with town stormwater management standards. 
5.  A landscaping and signage plan. Existing viable tree stands and vegetation shall be maintained on site to the degree practicable in accordance with the town's vegetation management policies. 
e.  Subject to approval of conditional use permit, the applicant shall submit a construction plat in accordance with article III of chapter 2., "Subdivision Regulations" of the Consolidated Development Ordinance. The construction plat shall be reviewed and approved by the town and all applicable state agencies prior to the issuance of a conditional use permit and site development work. 
f.  A plan for solid waste storage, collection and disposal shall be provided and approved by the town. 
(37)  Towers, poles, and antennas, commercial use. 
a.  All freestanding transmission towers, including television, radio, cellular or similar transmitting or receiving towers, shall have a setback of 250 feet from residentially zoned property and shall be located such that all supporting cables and anchors are contained within the property. Any tower that is over 250 feet in height shall have a setback equal to the height of the tower. Where towers are adjacent to nonresidentially zoned property, the setback shall equal 60 percent of the tower height. 
b.  Each tower may be accompanied by one maintenance or service structure not to exceed 400 square feet in size. 
c.  Security fencing at least six feet in height shall be installed around the base of the tower. 
d.  No business signs, billboards, or other advertising shall be installed on the tower. 
e.  All utility buildings and security fencing shall be screened from view of the public right-of-way. 
f.  A buffer that complies with the requirements of division 10 of this article shall be installed along all property lines. The town, at its discretion, may require additional buffering to protect surrounding land uses. 
(38)  Unified tract developments. 
a.  Purpose. The unified and planned development of a site, in single or corporate ownership at the time of development, may be permitted in a unified tract development (UTD) without the customary division into individual lots, subject to the regulations as provided in this subsection (38). For the purpose of this subsection (38), all UTD projects shall be classified as follows and shall be limited to parcels of not less than the size indicated: 
Residential: two acres 
Commercial: two acres 
b.  Application of regulations. 
1.  Uses allowed. Only those uses allowed as permitted uses in the district in which the tract is located shall be allowed in a unified tract development. If the tract is located within two or more districts, only those permitted uses common to all such districts shall be allowed. 
2.  Use and structure compliance. Individual structures and uses within a UTD need not comply with the specific building location, building size, floor area (variation may not exceed ten percent), lot size and open space requirements of the zoning district provided the spirit and intent of such requirements are complied with in the total development plan, it being the intent that variations in these items, but not in uses allowed in UTDs, shall be consistent with the criteria established in subsection (38)e of this section. 
c.  Coordination with subdivision regulations. The requirements of the town subdivision regulations shall apply to all unified tract developments. It is the intent of this division that any subdivision review and approval required by the subdivision regulations (article III of this chapter) be carried out simultaneously with the review of a UTD. The development plans submitted under this division must be submitted in a form that will satisfy the requirements of the subdivision regulations for preliminary and final plats. 
d.  Procedure. 
1.  Conditional use permit application. In addition to the conditional use permit submittal requirements of section 18-221, the following information shall accompany the submission as addenda to the conditional use permit application: 
i.  A statement describing the general character of the intended development along with such other pertinent information as may be necessary to make a determination that the contemplated arrangement or use makes it desirable to apply regulations and requirements differing from those ordinarily applicable in the zoning district. 
ii.  A general development plan of the project showing at least the following information as may be required by the planning board in a specific situation in sufficient detail to allow the planning board and the town council to apply the criteria for approval as set forth as follows: 
An accurate map of the project area including its relationship to surrounding properties; 
Statistical data on total size of the project area, area of open space, density computation and proposed number of residential units, impact on municipal services, and other data pertinent to a comprehensive development; 
The pattern of roads, driveways, and parking facilities, intended design standards; 
The size, arrangement and location of lots or of building groups; 
The type, size and location of structures; 
The location of water and sewer facilities; 
Architectural drawings and sketches illustrating the design and character of the proposed structures; 
The location of recreational open space areas and areas reserved or dedicated for public uses such as schools, parks, etc.; 
The general landscape treatment; 
The existing topography showing basic topographic changes to be made through construction; and 
A general outline of intended organization structure related to property owners association, deed restrictions, and provision of service. 
2.  Referral to planning board. A UTD petition shall be referred to the planning board and processed as any application for conditional use. Upon completion of necessary study and investigation, the planning board shall make its recommendations to the town council as to the appropriateness and desirability of the proposed change, the suitability of the building site and any development plans, and any additional conditions which it may feel to be necessary and appropriate. 
e.  Basis for approval. The planning board, in making its recommendations, and the town council, in making its determinations, shall give the consideration and satisfy themselves as to the following stipulations: 
1.  Scheduling intent and financing ability. The proponents of the proposed development shall demonstrate that they intend to start construction within an appropriately timed manner following the approval of the project, that the project appears economically sound, that adequate financing is possible, and that the development will be carried out according to a reasonable construction schedule satisfactory to the town. 
2.  Consistency and justification. The proposed development must be shown to be consistent in all respects to the spirit and intent of this section, to conform with the town's general plans for community development, to be supportive of the general welfare and economic prosperity of the town and of the immediate neighborhood, to have specific development plans prepared with competent professional advice and guidance, and to show that the benefits and improved design of the resultant development justified the variation from the normal requirements of this division and other policies and regulations of the town. 
3.  Residential development. It must be shown that: 
i.  Such development will create an attractive residential environment of sustained desirability, economic stability, compatible with the character established for the area by the land use plan, and where the economic impact of the development in terms of income levels, property values, and service demands is at least as beneficial to the community as that which could be anticipated in the underlying zoning district. 
ii.  The project will not create traffic or parking demand incompatible with that anticipated in the land use plan. 
iii.  The total average density of the project will be consistent with that permitted within the zoning district. The maximum allowable density shall be computed by dividing the total area within the project, excluding streets, by the lot size per unit permitted in the base zoning district. An increase in the allowable maximum density, not to exceed ten percent, may be permitted upon recommendation of the planning board, provided that the increased density is justified by the applicant's attention to preserving important natural features, wildlife habitat, recreational facilities, or other measures which enhance the physical environment of the project. 
iv.  The aggregate open space of the development will be no less than would have resulted from the application of open space requirements of section 18-451. 
v.  Adequate guarantee is provided for permanent retention as open space of the residential open land resulting from the application of these regulations, either by private reservation or by dedication to the public. 
vi.  In the case of private reservation of open area, the open area to be reserved shall be protected against building development, by recording with the register of deeds as part of the conditions for project approval, an open space easement restricting the area against any future building or use except as is consistent with that of providing landscaped open space for the aesthetic and recreational satisfaction of the surrounding residences. Buildings or uses for noncommercial recreational or cultural purposes compatible with the open space objective may be permitted only where specifically authorized as part of the development plan or subsequently with the express approval of the town council. 
vii.  Any common facilities for the project will be maintained by a management organization with authority to assess property owners within the project with the costs of maintaining the facilities. The manner of ensuring maintenance and assessing such costs shall be determined prior to the final approval of the project plans and shall be included in the title to each property involved. 
4.  Commercial development. It must be shown that: 
i.  The proposed development will be adequately served by off-street parking and truck service facilities. 
ii.  The locations for entrances and exits have been designed to prevent unnecessary interference with the safe and efficient movement of vehicular and pedestrian traffic on surrounding streets and walkways, and the development will not create an effect upon the general traffic pattern of the area incompatible with that anticipated in the land use plan. 
iii.  The architectural design, landscaping, control of lighting, and general site development will result in an attractive and harmonious service area creating a positive effect upon the property values of the surrounding neighborhood. 
f.  Determination. 
1.  The town council, after due consideration, may approve the application as submitted, approve the application with additional conditions or deny the application. 
2.  The authorization of a conditional use permit shall be based on assurance that the proposed development will be carried out basically as presented in the official submission plans. Detailed construction and engineering plans need not necessarily be completed at the time the UTD request is approved, but approval of the preliminary plan shall be conditioned upon the subsequent submittal and approval of more specific and detailed plans as the development progresses according to a schedule approved by the town council. 
3.  The developer shall be responsible for ensuring the implementation of the development according to the terms and conditions established as part of the development plan approval. 
4.  Any subsequent change or addition to the plans of use shall first be submitted for review by the planning board, and if in the opinion of the planning board such change or addition constitutes a substantial alteration of the original plan, a new public hearing shall be required. 
(38.5)  Veterinary clinics with associated kennels. 
a.  The property shall have frontage upon a collector or higher classification street. 
b.  The veterinary clinic or hospital may be permitted upon a finding that the use will not constitute a nuisance because of anticipated traffic, noise or odor. 
c.  Associated kennels or animal runs shall be located a minimum of 250 feet from any adjacent property boundary lines unless such kennels and runs are located within a fully enclosed, roofed, walled and soundproofed structure. 
(39)  Waterslide. 
a.  Buffers must be installed on all property lines abutting residentially zoned or used property in accordance with the requirements of this division. 
b.  Lighting installed on the property must comply with the provisions for town lighting in division 11 of this article and shall be installed in a manner that prevents trespass onto adjoining properties and controls glare on the public right-of-way and on public trust waters. 
c.  Required off-street parking spaces shall be provided. 
(Ord. of 6-12-2001, ch. 1, § 9.2; Ord. of 1-8-2002, § 8; Ord. of 5-14-2002, § 5; Ord. of 9-9-2002, § 7; Ord. of 11-12-2002, § 2; Ord. of 5-13-2003, § 3; Ord. of 7-13-2004; Amend. of 11-3-2004; Amend. of 1-11-2005; Amend. of 7-12-2005; Ord. of 9-11-2007; Amend. of 12-11-2007(2); Ord. of 8-12-2008(3); Ord. of 12-9-2008; Ord. of 3-10-2009; Amend. of 7-14-2009; Amend. of 4-13-2010; Amend. of 6-14-2011, § 3; Amend. of 11-13-2012; Amend. of 2-15-2016(2); Amend. of 10-11-2016(1)) 
Secs. 18-227-18-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - SIGNS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted July 12, 2005, amended div. 9, Signs, in its entirety and provided new provisions of similar material. Former §§ 18-251-18-260 derived from Ord. of 9-9-2002 and Ord. of 10-14-2003. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 26. 

Sec. 18-251. - Purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this section to permit signs of a commercial, industrial, and residential nature in districts that have appropriate uses and to regulate the size and placement of signs intended to be seen from the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005) 
Sec. 18-252. - Definitions. 
    Sign. Any words, lettering, figures, numerals, emblems, devices, trademarks or trade names, or any combination thereof, by which anything is made known and which is designed to attract attention and/or convey a message. The following shall not be included in the application of the regulations herein: 
(1)  Signs not exceeding one square foot in area and bearing only property numbers, post office box numbers, names of occupants of premises, or other identification of premises not having commercial connotation. 
(2)  Flags and insignias of any government except when displayed in connection with commercial promotion. 
(3)  Legal notices, identification, information, or directional signs erected or required by governmental bodies. 
(4)  Integral decorative or architectural features on buildings except letters, trademarks, moving parts, or moving lights. 
(5)  Signs directing and guiding traffic and parking on private property, but bearing no advertising matter. 
    Sign, A-frame, sandwich signs. Any sign, not permanently affixed or which is capable of being transported on its own chassis or by other mobile means. 
    Sign area. The entire face of a sign, computed as the extreme limits of the lettering or other display, together with any integral part of the background of the lettering or display, but not including the support framework, bracing, fence or wall upon which it is placed when such is clearly incidental to the display itself. In the case of a double faced sign, only one side is considered in computing sign area. 
    Sign, commercial accessory. A sign on a commercial parcel relating to the products sold thereon in addition to the principal use sign. 

    Sign, feather. A freestanding temporary sign typically constructed of a single plastic or metal or metal shaft driven in the ground with an attached pennant that is vertically elongated and attached to the shaft. 
    Sign, freestanding. A sign erected by means other than attachment to a building, canopy or marquee. 
    Sign, outdoor advertising. Any sign, including a standard poster panel either free standing or attached to a structure which directs attention to a business commodity, service, entertainment, or other activity conducted, sold, or offered elsewhere than on the premises on which said sign is located. Also commonly known as a billboard sign. 
    Sign, political. A sign that advertises a candidate or issue to be voted upon a definite election day. 
    Sign, portable. Any sign not permanently affixed or which is capable of being transported on its own chassis or by other mobile means. (See subsection 18-254(c)) 
    Sign, principal use. A sign which directs attention to a business, commodity, service, entertainment, or other activity conducted, sold, or offered on the premises upon which said sign is located. 
    Sign, projection. A sign attached to a building wall, canopy or marquee that by design projects more than 12 inches from the face of said building wall, canopy or marquee. 
    Sign, suspended or hanging. Any sign attached to a building, canopy or marquee that is not a wall or projection sign as defined in this Code. 
    Sign, temporary. Any sign that advertises or directs attention to a product, event, election, activity, meeting, exhibition or performance of any kind where such sign is not permanently affixed, placed, attached or erected, and is allowed for a limited timeframe. (See section 18-258). 
    Sign, wall. A sign permanently affixed to the wall of a building or structure. 
    Special event. A community event, open to the public and sponsored by non-commercial civic, charitable, community, bona fide non-profit or governmental organizations. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005; Amend. of 9-1-2005; Amend. of 11-15-2005; Amend. of 6-13-2017(2)) 
Sec. 18-253. - General provisions. 
(a)  All signs within the jurisdictional area covered by these regulations shall be erected, constructed and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this section. Only those signs listed in this section shall be erected within the jurisdictional area of this division. 
(b)  Any sign which requires a permit as set forth in this Code, shall meet the requirements set forth in the North Carolina Building Code for Coastal Wind Zones and shall be certified by a professional engineer to ensure specific design criteria are met (where applicable). 
(c)  Traffic safety. No sign shall be erected or continued that: 
(1)  Obstructs the sight distance at intersections or along the public right-of-way. 
(2)  Would tend by its location, color, or nature, to be confused with or obstruct the view of traffic signs or signals or would tend to be confused with a flashing light of an emergency vehicle. 
(3)  Uses admonitions such as stop, go, slow, danger, etc., which might be confused with traffic directional signs or signals. 
(d)  Setbacks. All signs that require a permit shall be setback at least ten feet from any property line. In the case a structure is erected to the property line, a wall sign shall be erected flush to the building and no lower than eight feet above sidewalk grade. Unless specifically exempted herein, signs that do not require a permit shall be located entirely within the property lines and situated so no traffic hazards are created. 
(e)  Maintenance. Should any sign become insecure or in danger of falling or otherwise unsafe in the opinion of the code enforcement official, the owner thereof, or the person or firm maintaining said sign, shall upon written notice served by first class mail, return receipt requested, bring said sign into conformity with the provisions of this Code, or remove such sign. If such order is not complied with in the ten days after receipt, the code enforcement official shall cause such sign to be removed at the expense of the owner. In cases where a sign poses an immediate threat to the public safety and welfare, the code enforcement official shall cause the sign to be made safe upon discovery of the threat. (Reference section 18-262) 
    All signs for which a permit is required, together with all their supports, braces, guys and anchors shall be kept in repair. The code enforcement official may order the removal of any sign that is not maintained in accordance with the provisions of this section. Such removal shall be at the expense of the owner or lessee. (Reference section 18-262) 
(f)  Construction prohibited. No sign shall be attached to or painted on any telephone pole, light pole, telegraph pole, fence or other manmade object not intended to support a sign or any tree, rock or other natural object. 
(g)  Illumination. Illumination devices such as, but not limited to, flood or spot lights, shall be so placed and so shielded as to prevent the rays of illumination from being cast upon residential districts or any structure being used primarily for residential purposes, neighboring buildings and/or vehicles from any direction. 
    Blinking, flashing, oscillating or animated lights are prohibited for signs or as a means of advertising or attracting attention to a business establishment. This applies to all signs, permanent or portable (where allowed by special events permitting). Revolving barbershop light, electronic message displays where copy changes no more often than 60 seconds, and time and temperature displays are exempt. 
(h)  Nonconforming signs. All signs or advertising structures located in districts where they would not be permitted as a new use under the terms of these regulations are hereby declared to be nonconforming uses. Such nonconforming uses shall be discontinued and removed within three years after receiving notification of such nonconformity from the code enforcement official. If said nonconforming use is continued beyond the stated period, the code enforcement official shall cause same to be removed at the expense of the owner of nonconforming use. (Reference section 18-262). Excepting those outdoor advertising signs holding a valid permit from the department of transportation, all nonconforming off premises signs within the jurisdiction of the town shall be removed by December 31, 2008. The code enforcement officer shall notify property owners in writing of their obligation to remove such signs. 
(i)  Unlawful signs. In case any sign shall be installed, erected or constructed in violation of any of the terms of this division, the code enforcement official shall notify by first class mail return receipt requested or by written notice served personally, the owner or lessee thereof to alter such sign so as to comply with this Code and to secure the necessary permit therefore, or to remove the sign. If such order is not complied with in ten days of receipt, the code enforcement official shall remove such sign at the expense of the owner or lessee thereof. 
(j)  Combination of allowed signage permitted. Allowed signage may be combined but in no case shall the square footage exceed the limits set for the type of sign. When signage is combined, the total number of signs allowed will be reduced by the code enforcement official. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005) 
Sec. 18-254. - Prohibited signs. 
(a)  Signs erected on or over public streets. No sign shall be erected or maintained within any public street right-of-way nor be allowed to extend over or into any public area, except for wall signs on a building built to the right-of-way line. Such signs must be erected flush against the building, and no lower than eight feet above sidewalk grade. This subsection shall not apply to signs required to be posted by law, open house signs and signs deemed necessary by the town in the furtherance of a governmental, public or civic interest. 
(b)  Signs obstructing ingress or egress of building. No sign shall be erected or maintained that obstructs ingress and/or egress to or from any window, door, fire escape, stairway, ladder or opening intended to provide light, air, ingress or egress to or from any room or building as required by law. 
(c)  Portable signs. Any sign not permanently affixed or which is capable of being transported on its own chassis or by other mobile means. This subsection shall not apply to government or non-profit organizations that have obtained a valid special event(s) permit as set forth in section 18-258 of this Code. For purposes of these regulations, portable signs shall not be defined as magnetic signs on vehicles displaying business logos, official identification, advertising, or campaign signs when all other requirements of this section are met. 
(d)  All off-premises signs, including but not limited to real estate directional signs, private advertisement, for sale by owner, etc., are prohibited, except as noted in section 18-256 for open house or promotional sales signs. 
(e)  Excepting those for which a valid permit is currently issued from the department of transportation, no outdoor advertising sign shall be permitted within the jurisdiction. 

(f)  Flashing, fluttering, swinging, rotating signs (except governmental signs and signs, which give time and temperature and other commercial public information message) such as an inflatable air dancer is prohibited. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005; Amend. of 9-1-2005; Amend. of 11-15-2005; Amend. of 6-13-2017(2)) 
Sec. 18-255. - Signs requiring permit. 
    No sign, unless specifically exempted herein, may be erected, moved, enlarged or substantially altered except in accordance with the following requirements and standards: 
(1)  Wall signs. Wall signs shall be permitted as long as they meet the following requirements: 
a.  Wall signs shall not project more than ten inches from any building wall or canopy, and must maintain a minimum of eight feet from the bottom of the sign to the sidewalk grade. 
b.  Wall signs shall not extend above parapet walls or above rooflines of buildings without parapet walls. If the roof is a mansard type roof the sign may be attached flat against but may not extend above said roof. 
c.  Except as provided in section 18-259 below, wall signs shall have a maximum sign surface area of 64 square feet or a square footage no greater than two times the linear frontage in feet of the wall of the building to which said sign is attached, whichever is less. In the case of a shared frontage, only the linear footage equal to the width of the unit may be used to calculate sign area. 
(2)  Freestanding signs. Except as provided in section 18-259 below, freestanding signs shall be limited to 64 square feet in area and shall not exceed a height of 24 feet. 
a.  Any freestanding sign that is elevated on posts, pilings, or by single pole must maintain a minimum height of eight feet from the bottom of said sign to the ground or pedestrian walkway grade. 
(3)  Projection signs. Projection signs will be allowed as long as they project no more than three feet from a flat surface of the building, canopy, or marquee and have a maximum square footage of 12 feet and there is eight feet from the bottom of the sign to pedestrian walkway grade. 
(4)  Feather signs. No more than two are permissible for each business. No sign shall be erected or maintained that obstructs ingress and/or egress to or from property or opening intended to provide ingress or egress to or from any room or building as required by law. The sign permit fee codified in the town adopted fee schedule shall apply one time for each individual new sign. Such signage cannot be a visual impairment to road signage as determined by the planning and zoning administrator or his/her designee, cannot be lighted or exceed ten feet in height. Feather signs must be securely attached with an auger or a similar device as approved by the town. 
(5)  A-frame, sandwich signs. No more than two are permissible for each business. No sign shall be erected or maintained that obstructs ingress and/or egress to or from property or opening intended to provide ingress or egress to or from any room or building as required by law. The sign permit fee codified in the town adopted fee schedule shall apply one time for each individual new sign. Such signage cannot be a visual impairment to road signage as determined by the planning and zoning administrator or his/her designee. A-frame and sandwich signs may not exceed two by three feet in dimensions, a total of 12 square feet, and cannot be lighted. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005; Amend. of 3-8-2016(1); Amend. of 6-13-2017(2)) 
Sec. 18-256. - Signs that do not require permits. 
    The following signs may be erected without a permit, but shall not be illuminated unless otherwise specified: 
(1)  Temporary real estate signs. 
a.  Residential-One temporary residential real estate sign not to exceed six square feet in size may be erected. Where the property on which said sign is placed faces more than one street, one sign shall be allowed on each street frontage. The signs are only allowed on the property being advertised. In addition to the real estate sign, two six inch by 24 inch addendum may be added to the sign to list the agent, company, or contact name and number. 
b.  Commercial-One temporary real estate sign not to exceed 16 square feet may be placed on the property being advertised. Where the property on which said sign is placed has frontage on more than one public street, one sign shall be allowed on each street frontage. 
c.  Property management sign-One property management sign not to exceed four square feet shall be permitted on each street frontage. 
d.  Open house or sales promotional signs shall be limited to one directional sign at the main street corner and one sign on the street corner where property is located. On site signage may consist of one of each of the following: open house, flag or banner, listing agency sign. All signs in this category shall be limited to six square feet in size, may only be placed at the beginning of each sale day, and must be removed at the end of each sale day. 
e.  Multi-unit structures-The following limitations will apply to sales signs in multi-unit complexes: 
1.  Only one general "For Sale" sign will be allowed at the street, not to exceed the size limits above. 
2.  One central bulletin board or general information sign to list units for sale will be allowed at each building, not to exceed nine square feet. 
3.  One listing agency or personal "For Sale" sign not to exceed six square feet may be attached to an individual unit's window or door. 
4.  No sign shall be attached or affixed to any other part of the structure; including but not limited to, stairs, rails, posts, parking areas, yards or other public areas. 
(2)  Temporary construction sign. Temporary construction site signage may be allowed within a ten square foot ground area and under the following conditions: 
a.  Residential construction-One temporary construction site sign not to exceed 16 square feet, advertising the name of the general contractor, architect, designer, or engineer may be erected during construction. If subcontractors are listed, sign size may be increased to 32 square feet. 
b.  Commercial construction-One temporary construction site sign shall be allowed announcing the names of the general contractor, subcontractors, architect, engineer, landscape designer, finance agency. The sign shall not exceed 36 square feet. Independent subcontractors may erect signage not to exceed four square feet. 
(3)  Bulletin boards. Churches, schools, community centers and other public and institutional uses may erect one sign or bulletin board not exceeding 16 square feet in area for the purpose of displaying the name of the institution and related information. Such signs shall be used as wall signs or shall be located a minimum of ten feet from the main structure unless incorporated as part of the principle sign allowed in section 18-255. 
(4)  Home occupation sign. One sign that shall not exceed one square foot. 
(5)  Direction, information or instructional sign. Direction or information signs of a public or quasi-public nature shall not exceed 12 square feet in area. Such signs shall only be used for the purpose of stating or calling attention to: 
a.  The name of location of the city, community center, or place of worship. 
b.  The name of a place of meeting or an official or civic body such as the Chamber of Commerce, service club or fraternal organization. 
c.  Events of public interest including but not limited to: public hearing; general election; church or public meeting; local or county fair; and other similar community activities and campaigns. 
d.  Signs erected strictly for the direction, safety or convenience of the public, including signs which identify restrooms, parking area entrances or exits, and no trespassing signs or similar devices warning of danger. 
e.  Soil conservation, 4-H and similar projects. 
f.  Zoning and subdivision jurisdiction boundaries. 
(6)  Temporary yard/garage sale signs. 
a.  A maximum of two signs no greater than six square feet may be posted in the right-of-way, so long as said signs do not interfere with vehicular traffic or line of sight of any traffic thereby creating a danger upon the streets of the town. 
b.  All signs shall be removed by 5:00 p.m. on the day of the sale. The removal of the signs shall be the responsibility of the owner of property where the yard sale is located. Signs picked up by the code enforcement official will result in fines as described in section 18-261. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005) 
Sec. 18-257. - Political signs. 
    Political signs may be displayed during periods of national, state and local primary or general elections subject to the following limitations and regulations: 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  May not exceed six square feet in size, with no lighting or moveable parts. Height may not exceed 42 inches from ground to top of sign. 
(3)  Not permitted within a public right-of-way or other public property nor attached to traffic sign poles, utility/telephone or other public poles. 
a.  Exception. Signs may be placed in an area adjacent to the buffer zone for each voting place on election day and at one-stop voting sites as determined by the county board of elections as authorized under G.S. 163.166-4. 
(4)  Shall not be located within 50 feet of the intersection of any two major thoroughfares (i.e. the intersections of Country Club and East Oak Island Drive, Oak Island Drive and 58th St., Oak Island Drive and Middleton, 40th St. and Oak Island Dr. 
(5)  Reserved. 
(6)  Violation procedures for political signage: 
a.  It is the responsibility of the candidate to educate his/her supporters of these rules. Candidates for local office (or local political party headquarters for state or national offices) will be notified on the first business day after filing deadline with a copy of the rules. 
b.  Public property: All noncompliant signs will be removed from all forms of public property by the code enforcement official in accordance with section 18-261. The town will not be responsible for damage to signs removed for violations. 
c.  Private property: Official notice of violation (either verbal or written) will be issued by the code enforcement official upon discovery of noncompliant signs. The official notice subjects property owners to immediate levy of fines of $50.00 per day. However, the political candidate or local political party headquarters will be notified at least 48 hours before notice of violation is served on the property owner. Whenever possible, candidates or political parties should attempt to remedy constituent violations prior to issuance of notice/levy of fines by the code enforcement official. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005; Amend. of 9-1-2005; Ord. of 2-17-2009) 
State Law reference- G.S. 163-166.4. Limitation on activity in the voting place and in a buffer zone around it. 
Sec. 18-258. - Special event signage. 
    Any organization of a civic, non-profit, public, quasi-public or governmental nature that sponsors a special event for which announcement signage is desired shall apply for a temporary sign permit to place temporary sign(s), banner(s) or other means of announcing the event within the jurisdiction of the town. Such application must be filed a minimum of five working days before signs are posted. A representative designated by the sponsoring group shall provide an installation and removal plan for review by the planning director, who shall grant written permission if the standards below are met. 
(1)  Temporary special event signs may be placed not more than ten days before the special event and shall be removed within 48 hours following the conclusion of the event unless otherwise specified on the special events permit. Not more than four special events per year shall be issued sign permits for the same sponsoring organization unless approved by the town manager. 
(2)  Special event signs or banners shall be located outside of the public right-of-way or more than 11 feet from pavement, whichever is greater. Cross-street banners for community events may be approved by NCDOT or the town manager, as applicable. 
(3)  Special event signs or banners shall be limited to six such signs and shall not exceed 64 square feet each. 
(4)  Special event signs or banners shall be separated by not less than 200 feet. 
(5)  Special event signs are prohibited upon trees, utility poles, traffic control signs or devices. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005) 
Sec. 18-259. - Special provisions for commercial signage. 
    The following types of business uses shall adhere to these special provisions in addition to the general provisions set forth in this division: 
(1)  Each business, unless it is located within a shopping center or business condominium development or specifically addressed elsewhere in this Code, shall be allowed on the premises of said business, one principal use sign not to exceed 64 square feet and two commercial accessory signs. The total square footage of the accessory signs shall not exceed 36 square feet. 
(2)  Where a business has frontage on two public streets, one additional principal use sign shall be permitted on each street frontage. 
(3)  Termination of business. Within 30 days after the termination of business at a particular location, the owner of the sign shall remove or eliminate all signs related to the terminated or relocated business. If the owner of the sign fails to remove the sign within 30 days, the code enforcement official shall cause said sign to be removed at the expense of the owner. 
(4)  Shopping centers and/or business condominium development on Oak Island (i.e., located to the south or east of the Intracoastal Waterway) may provide one freestanding sign that displays the name of the center or development and the tenant businesses. Such signs shall not exceed a total sign surface area of 64 square feet relating to the center or development plus 12 square feet per individual tenant business within the shopping center. Each tenant within the center or development may have one wall sign not to exceed 18 square feet. 
(5)  Freestanding signs at mainland shopping centers. Notwithstanding the limitations of sections 18-255(2) and 18-259(4) above, shopping centers and/or business condominium development on the mainland (i.e., located to the north or west of the Intracoastal Waterway) may provide the following freestanding signs: 
a.  One freestanding sign along each public right-of-way frontage that displays the name of the center or development and one or more tenant businesses. Such signs shall not exceed a sign surface area of 125 square feet per face, and may not exceed 25 feet in total height. All total combined freestanding signage cannot exceed 250 square feet per sign. 
b.  One freestanding sign for each individual parcel with one or more tenants within the center or development. Such signs shall not exceed a sign surface area of 64 square feet per face, and may not exceed six feet in total height and width being no greater than twice the height. 
(6)  Wall signs at mainland shopping centers. Notwithstanding the limitations of sections 18-255(1) and 18-259(4) above, wall signs at shopping centers and/or business condominium developments on the mainland (i.e., located to the north or west of the Intracoastal Waterway) shall be permitted as long as they meet the following requirements: 
a.  Wall signs shall not project more than ten inches from any building wall or canopy, and must maintain a minimum of eight feet from the bottom of the sign to the sidewalk grade. 
b.  Wall signs shall not extend ten inches below parapet walls or rooflines of buildings without parapet walls. If the roof is a mansard type roof, the sign may be attached flat against but may not extend above said roof, and shall be placed as set forth above. 
c.  Each wall sign for a tenant occupying equal to or more than 35,000 square feet gross floor area shall have a maximum surface area (in square feet) of (i) 150 square feet or (ii) two times the linear frontage (in feet) of the wall of the building to which such sign is attached, whichever is less and two commercial accessory signs. Such a tenant may have no more than 350 square feet of total signage. 
d.  Each wall sign for a tenant occupying less than 35,000 sf gross floor area shall be considered accessory use signage and shall have a maximum surface area (in square feet) of (i) two times the linear frontage (in feet) of the wall of the building to which such sign is attached, (ii) 100 square feet, or (iii) 80 percent of the sign band area, whichever is less, and two commercial accessory signs. Such a tenant may have no more than 200 square feet of total signage. In the case of a shared frontage, only the linear footage equal to the width of the unit may be used to calculate sign area. 
(7)  Franchised and combination businesses located on one premises or within the same building; including but not limited to service stations, convenience stores/food shops and like enterprises, shall adhere to the following: 
a.  Signs required by federal or state regulations, such as gasoline price signs, are allowed in those districts where required. Such signs shall be the minimum size required by law and shall be calculated as a portion of the allowed signage. 
b.  The principal business use shall be determined by which business utilizes the largest area of the property. The principal business shall be provided one principal use sign not to exceed 64 square feet and one accessory sign not to exceed 24 square feet. The secondary business shall be allowed one wall sign not to exceed 32 square feet. In cases where the property is shared equally, one principal use sign not to exceed 64 square feet shall be shared by the business and each individual business shall be permitted one accessory wall sign not to exceed 24 square feet. 
c.  Product associated signage, logos and insignia normally associated with products placed on the exterior of the business structure and which the signage is not controlled by the operator shall not be calculated in the allowed signage. This associated signage includes but is not limited to signage on gasoline and other fuel pumps, ice storage bins/freezers, propane cylinder storage racks and other like items which bear the name of the manufacturer or supplier not otherwise associated with the business. 
(8)  Temporary signs for the advertisements of special pricing events, sales, offers, and products shall be limited to two per premises at any given time and shall be displayed only during hours of operation. Temporary signage must meet the setback requirements and other general provisions of this Code. The maximum sign area shall be limited to 12 square feet. 
(9)  Temporary banners and flags for special events, liquidation, national holidays and in conjunction with multi-unit residential and commercial building projects or enterprise are allowed for a period not to exceed 90 calendar days within the same year and that based on the size listed below. An application for a sign permit must be filled out for every banner and subject to the approved fee schedule. 
Size and quantity: The size of each banner is to be limited to 30 percent of the total square footage of the facade of which it is to be affixed. The number of banners allowed per applicant is to be no more than two if the primary structure has frontage on two streets. 
a.  No banner shall exceed 1600 square feet or 800 square feet for structures on two street frontages. 
b.  All banners shall be attached to the street frontage wall of the principle structure. If the primary wall fronts a parking lot, then banner may be attached to such wall. 
c.  No such banner shall be attached to any roof structure. If possible, banners should not be hung in window spaces and shall not be hung as to impede the emergency egress of the structure. 
d.  Vinyl banners are permitted, provided that the banner is secured tightly to the building. No loose, non-secure attachments are allowed. 
e.  All banners must be maintained and in good condition. If any banner is found to be in poor condition, the code official shall require its removal within 24 hours. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005; Amend. of 7-10-2012; Amend. of 3-8-2016(1)) 
Sec. 18-260. - Administration, filing procedure and permits. 
(a)  Administration. The code enforcement official shall only issue a permit for the erection or construction of a sign that meets the requirements of this section. 
(b)  Filing procedures. Application for permits to erect, hang place or alter the structure of a sign shall be submitted on forms obtainable from the code enforcement official. Each application shall be accompanied by a plan showing the following: 
(1)  Area of the sign. 
(2)  Size, character, general layout, and designs proposed for painted displays. 
(3)  The method and type of illumination, if any. 
(4)  The location proposed for such signs in relation to building, property line, zoning district boundaries, rights-of-way lines, and existing signs. 
(5)  If conditions warrant it, the code enforcement official may require such additional information as will enable him to determine if such sign is to be erected in conformity with these regulations. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005) 
Sec. 18-261. - Removal of illegal signs on public property. 
    All illegal signs on all forms of public property shall be removed and held at development services building for not more than seven days. Removed signs may be retrieved during that time by owners upon release by the code enforcement official and payment of $25.00 handling fee per sign plus any fine levied for the violation. After seven days, all signs removed from public property shall be considered disposable. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005) 
Sec. 18-262. - Removal and abatement of illegal signs-Penalties. 
    A violation of this division shall be punishable by a fine of $50.00 each day for the first ten days following the deadline given for abatement of the violation. The town may also recover costs for staff inspection time, mailings or other service of notices and costs incurred for abatement of the nuisance. 
    Following the initial ten-day penalty period, a penalty of $250.00 per day shall be imposed for each day that the violation goes unabated. 
    All unpaid penalties shall be filed as a lien against real property and collected as unpaid taxes. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005) 
Sec. 18-263. - Enforcement appeals for extended abatement time. 
    The town manager or his designee may make reasonable rulings on appeals for additional time to abate violations of this division based on extenuating circumstances. Such rulings shall be made in writing and shall specify the reasons for and the conditions of specific time extensions granted. 
(Ord. of 7-12-2005) 
Sec. 18-264. - Table of permitted and prohibited signs.

Secs. 18-265-18-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 10. - BUFFERS 

Sec. 18-281. - General requirements. 
(a)  Each application for a building permit or certificate of occupancy shall include, for those districts where a buffer is required, information as to the location and type of buffer to be erected. Buffering shall provide a yearround visual screen in order to minimize adverse impacts. It may consist of fencing, evergreens, berms, or combinations thereof. Plant materials shall be appropriate for coastal North Carolina and shall be selected from "Seacoast Plants of the Carolinas," published by the University of North Carolina Sea Grant Program. 
(b)  Once erected, a buffer shall be properly maintained. The construction and maintenance of the buffer shall be the responsibility of the landowner or developer. 
(c)  A buffer shall be a six-foot high attractive visual barrier that will reduce noise where needed. 
(Ord. of 6-12-2001, ch. 1, § 11.1) 
Sec. 18-282. - Requirements for the airport district. 
    For any of the permitted uses which involve outdoor storage, or operation, a vegetative buffer and/or screen of 15 feet which achieves an opacity of 80 percent yearround to a height of ten feet shall be provided adjacent to property either zoned for or used for residential purposes. 
(Ord. of 6-12-2001, ch. 1, § 11.2; Ord. of 7-9-2002, § 2) 
Secs. 18-283-18-288. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 11. - LIGHTING 

Sec. 18-289. - Purpose. 
    This division sets forth criteria for the installation of exterior lighting and lighting visible from the exterior of buildings and structures, the purposes of which are as follows: 
(1)  Preserve and enhance public safety; 
(2)  Protect drivers from disabling glare and thereby enhance traffic safety; 
(3)  Enhance the town's nighttime character; 
(4)  Shield neighboring properties from nuisance glare; 
(5)  Reduce light pollution; 
(6)  Protect sea turtle hatchlings from disorienting light; and 
(7)  Promote energy conservation through efficient light design and operation. 
(Ord. of 4-11-2000, § 9-141(a)) 
Sec. 18-290. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cutoff fixture means fixtures shielded so that no more than 2.5 percent of their light output is emitted above 90 degrees at any lateral angle around the fixture. 
    Fixture means an assembly that houses the lamp and can include all or some of the following parts: a housing, a mounting bracket or pole socket, a lamp holder, a ballast, a reflector or mirror, and/or a refractor or lens. 
    Fully-shielded lights means outdoor light fixtures shielded or constructed so that no light rays are emitted by the installed fixture at angles above the horizontal plane. 
    Glare means light emitted from a light fixture with intensity great enough to reduce a viewer's ability to see, and in extreme cases, causing momentary blindness. 
    Lamp means part of the fixture that produces actual light. 
    Light trespass means the shining of light produced by a light fixture beyond the boundaries of the property on which it is located. 
    Lumen means total quantity of light produced by a light source. 
    Outdoor lighting means nighttime illumination of an outside area, object, or building by any manmade device located outdoors or indoors that produces light by any means. 
    Temporary outdoor lighting means artificial illumination of an outside area for a period of less than seven days, with at least 90 days passing before being used again. 
    Uplighting means, for pole-mounted or wall-mounted fixtures, light that projects above an imaginary horizontal plane through the fixture; for fixtures intended to light a nonresidential building, light that projects above the lowest roofline. 
(Ord. of 4-11-2000, § 9-141(b)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-291. - Commercial parking lots and driveways. 
    Lighting for parking lots and driveways shall be designed to provide the minimum lighting necessary to ensure adequate public safety, to control excessive glare onto adjacent streets and properties, and to prevent light trespass onto adjoining properties. Light fixtures for parking lots may also illuminate structures served by the parking lot. 
(1)  All lighting fixtures used for the purpose of illuminating parking lots and driveways shall be cutoff fixtures. 
(2)  Directional or floodlighting fixtures must be shielded and properly aimed so that they control glare, do not produce uplighting, and contain light so that it does not encroach on neighboring properties and rights-of-way. 

Example of Cutoff Fixture 
(3)  The maximum mounting height for pole-mounted fixtures intended to illuminate parking lots is 25 feet measured from the base of the pole. 

Example of pole-mounted fixture 
(4)  Special design areas may require the use of lighting fixtures of a particular period or architectural style. In such areas, fixtures that are not cut off, as defined by IESNA, are permitted provided that the maximum initial lumens generated by each lamp shall not exceed 9,500 lumens; the fixtures meet the requirements for sea turtle protection in section 18-295; and post top fixtures are fitted with a solid top and open-bottom and dusk-to-dawn lights are fitted with skycap aluminum reflectors to control uplighting and reduce glare. 

Example of permitted special area lighting 
Temporary lighting is permitted if it meets the requirements for sea turtle protection in section 18-295. 
(Ord. of 4-11-2000, § 9-141(c)) 
Sec. 18-292. - Illumination of commercial buildings. 
    Buildings may be lighted with lighting equipment mounted in front, at ground level, or with wall-mounted down lighting fixtures provided that: 
(1)  Light fixtures are properly aimed and shielded to confine the light to the area of the building being lighted and to prevent light from encroaching on neighboring properties and adjoining public rights-of-way. 

Control uplighting 
(2)  Building mounted light fixtures may not be mounted more than 20 feet in height above grade. These fixtures must be shielded and aimed in a manner that controls uplighting. 
(3)  Ground-mounted fixtures must control uplighting. 

By definition light must not project 
(4)  Bare light sources (including but not limited to incandescent, fluorescent, high intensity discharge, and neon) used to outline property lines, open sales areas, rooflines, doors, windows, the edges of walls or any other area of the building or property visible from outside the building are prohibited, except for holiday lighting permitted from Thanksgiving through January 15 of the new year. 
(Ord. of 4-11-2000, § 9-141(d)) 
Sec. 18-293. - Residential areas (including private docks and piers). 
(a)  Fixtures using lamps (bulbs) of 150 watts or less, such as typical porch lights, may be installed at any location in residentially zoned areas except those located within sea turtle protection areas. 
(b)  Unshielded floodlights installed for security and activated by motion sensors are permitted. All other floodlight fixtures must have top and side shields capable of containing light below the roofline of the house and reducing light trespass on adjoining properties. 
(c)  Area lights, or dusk-to-dawn lights are permitted. These lights must be equipped with a skycap to control glare and to prevent uplighting. 
(1)  If pole-mounted, the fixture mounting height may be no more than 20 feet above grade at the base of the pole. 
(2)  If wall-mounted, the fixture mounting height may be no more than 16 feet above grade, or 16 feet above any deck or porch of houses constructed on pilings. 
(Ord. of 4-11-2000, § 9-141(e)) 
Sec. 18-294. - Signs. 
(a)  Lighting fixtures used to illuminate on-premises or off-premises outdoor commercial signs must be mounted at the top of the sign structure. 

Example of properly mounted sign light 
(b)  The sign lighting fixture(s) must be shielded to control glare, to prevent encroachment on neighboring properties and rights-of-way and to contain light so that it is projected below a horizontal plane extending through the fixture. 
(c)  The height of the sign lighting fixture shall be no greater than the maximum permitted height of the sign. 
(Ord. of 4-11-2000, § 9-141(f)) 
Sec. 18-295. - Sea turtle protection. 
    The purpose of this section is to protect the threatened and endangered sea turtles that nest along the beaches of the town by safeguarding egg-laying females and hatchlings from sources of artificial light that deter nesting and cause disorientation and subsequent death. To the maximum extent feasible and consistent with requirements for public safety, it is the policy of the town that no artificial light shall directly or indirectly illuminate the town's ocean beach and that the sources of lighting in the sea turtle protection area. To comply with this policy, outdoor lighting installed or upgraded within 300 feet of the primary dune after the effective date of this division shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Streetlights shall utilize cutoff fixtures and the fixtures shall be mounted no more than 25 feet above grade. 
(2)  Streetlight fixtures shall be shielded and/or utilize lenses to create a light pattern that contains light landward of the primary dune. 

Streetlights use cutoff fixtures 
(3)  Where it is impractical to contain light from streetlight fixtures on the landward side of the primary dune, colored lenses that modify light so that it is not disruptive to sea turtle hatchlings shall be employed. 
(4)  Pole-mounted light fixtures installed on private property shall be cutoff fixtures and shall be shielded in such a manner as to contain light on the landward side of the primary dune. The fixture mounting height may be no more than 20 feet above grade at the base of the pole. 
(5)  Wall-mounted light fixtures shall be fitted with shields and hoods to contain light on the landward side of the primary dune. 
(6)  Floodlights installed for security purposes and operated by motion sensors are permitted. To the maximum extent feasible, these fixtures shall be mounted and aimed in a manner to contain light on the landward side of the primary dune. 
(7)  Where possible, the source(s) of light within the 300-foot zone must not be visible from the seaward side of the primary dune. 

Pole-mounted lights must use cutoff fixtures 
(Ord. of 4-11-2000, § 9-141(g)) 
Sec. 18-296. - Implementation; compliance. 
    Building, electrical, and/or sign permits will state that the applicant must comply with the requirements of this division, and the requirements of this division must be met prior to the final inspection on the permit. 
(Ord. of 4-11-2000, § 9-141(h)) 
Secs. 18-297-18-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - ESTABLISHMENT OF VESTED RIGHTS 

Sec. 18-301. - Purpose of division. 
    On occasion areas within the zoning jurisdiction of the town may be rezoned to a new classification, and on occasion areas may be annexed into the zoning jurisdiction of the town and the town's zoning for the newly annexed area may be different than that previously existing for the area in question. Likewise, land use and development regulations may from time to time be amended or modified in a manner that could negatively impact development proposals approved previously for which permits have not yet been issued. This division is for the specific purpose of protecting those landowners who have made substantial expenditures in good faith reliance on a valid governmental approval for a certain use or development of property based on the preexisting land use regulations, or lack thereof, and who would suffer a substantial detriment if required to comply with the newly adopted zoning requirements. 
(Ord. of 6-12-2001, ch. 1, § 15.1; Ord. of 1-8-2002, § 15.1) 
Sec. 18-302. - Changes after issuance of building permit. 
    Amendments, modifications, supplements, repeal or other changes in zoning regulations and restrictions and zone boundaries shall not be applicable or enforceable without the consent of the owner with regard to buildings and uses for which building permits have been issued pursuant to G.S. 160A-417 prior to the enactment of the ordinance making the change so long as the building permit remains valid and unexpired pursuant to G.S. 160A-418 and unrevoked pursuant to G.S. 160A-422. Notwithstanding the provisions of these sections, a building permit shall not expire or be revoked because of the running of time while an established vested right as set forth in this division is outstanding. 
(Ord. of 6-12-2001, ch. 1, § 15.2; Ord. of 1-8-2002, § 15.2) 
Sec. 18-303. - Vested rights after plan approval. 
(a)  A vested right shall be deemed to have been established with respect to any property upon the valid approval, or conditional approval, of a site-specific development plan or a phased development plan, following notice and public hearing by the town/county having jurisdiction over the property. A vested right means the landowner shall have the right to undertake and complete the development and use of the property in accordance with the specific terms and conditions of the approved site specific or phased development plan. Failure of the landowner to comply with the terms and conditions of an approved or conditionally approved site-specific development plan will result in a forfeiture of vested rights. A site-specific development plan shall be deemed to have been approved upon the effective date of the town's/county's action or ordinance relating thereto. 
(b)  Once a vested right has been established in accordance with subsection (a) of this section, this right shall remain vested for a period of two years and this vesting may be extended for a period of up to five years by a majority vote of the town council where warranted in light of all relevant circumstances including, but not limited to, the size and phasing of development, the level of investment, the need for the development, economic cycles, and market conditions. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, land development approvals authorized prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall automatically expire within two years of such date when the following circumstances are in evidence: 
(1)  The development permits or permit applications authorized by such prior approval have not been filed with or applied for through the development services department. 
(2)  The land use authorized by such prior approval has not been commenced, under circumstances where no substantial site preparation or construction work would be necessary prior to the commencement of such use. 
(3)  The land use authorized by such prior approval has been commenced but has subsequently been discontinued for a period of at least two years. 
(Ord. of 6-12-2001, ch. 1, § 15.3; Ord. of 1-8-2002, § 15.3) 
Sec. 18-304. - Extension of vested rights. 
(a)  The landowner shall have the obligation to seek an extension of time for vested rights beyond the two-year period by filing an application for the extension with the town clerk with copies to be delivered to the office of development services or its successor for review and commentary to the town council. The town council may extend the period for vested rights for up to five years on its own motion but absent an application from the landowner or council action the time period for vested rights shall be two years. 
(b)  The town council may, but shall not be required to, refer the application to the planning board for its review and recommendation. The town council may require the landowner to submit site-specific development plans for approval by the town for each phase in order to obtain final approval to develop within the restrictions of the vested zoning classification. Following approval, the office of development services may from time to time conduct reviews and periodic inspections, in addition to its regular building code inspections, to ensure compliance with the terms and conditions of the original approval and compliance with the zoning classification under which the approval was issued. 
(Ord. of 6-12-2001, ch. 1, § 15.4; Ord. of 1-8-2002, § 15.4) 
Sec. 18-305. - Required statement by owner. 
    In each case, the affected landowner seeking vested rights shall have the responsibility to file a statement with the town clerk with a copy to the office of development services declaring his belief that he has established vested rights on the property in question along with any proof he may have of such rights. This statement must be filed prior to the passage of any annexation article, extension of extraterritorial jurisdiction ordinance or the passage of any rezoning ordinance or land use regulation amendment. Failure to file by the property owner within this time frame will result in forfeiture of any vested rights they might have claimed. The town, in consultation with the town attorney, shall make an initial determination of whether or not vested rights have been established. If the landowner disagrees with this determination, then he may, within 30 days of the date of such written determination, appeal the matter to the full town council for hearing. 
(Ord. of 6-12-2001, ch. 1, § 15.5; Ord. of 1-8-2002, § 15.5) 
Sec. 18-306. - Definitions. 
    The definitions as set forth in G.S. 160A-385.1 as the same may be amended from time to time are incorporated in this section by reference and made applicable to this article. 
(Ord. of 6-12-2001, ch. 1, § 15.6; Ord. of 1-8-2002, § 15.6) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 18-307-18-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 18-331. - Administrative official. 
(a)  The town council shall appoint the zoning administrator pursuant to G.S. 160A-388(b1)(2) to administer and enforce this article. The assistance of such other persons may be provided as the town council may direct. 
(b)  If the zoning administrator shall find that any of the provisions of this article are being violated, he shall notify the person responsible for such violation, ordering the action necessary to correct it. He shall order discontinuance of illegal use of land, buildings or structures; or of additions, alterations or structural changes thereto; discontinuance of any illegal work being done; or shall take any action authorized by this article to ensure compliance with or to prevent violation of its provisions. 
(c)  No oversight or dereliction of duties on the part of the zoning administrator, inspector or other official or employee of the development services department shall be deemed to legalize a violation of this article. 
(Ord. of 6-12-2001, ch. 1, § 13.1; Amend. of 3-11-2014(3)) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 
Sec. 18-332. - Building permit.
