Debris must be placed in the right-of-way in front of that resident's property and shall be out of the paved roadway, cannot obstruct stormwater assets or ditches, must be placed away from sewer clean outs, water meters, electrical lines and in accordance with other instructions that shall be published by the town, for collection by the town. The debris shall not be placed in any other area without written permissions from the other property owner affected and shall be submitted to the public works director. Debris pickup is not a service provided to a landscaping firm, a private tree company or to individuals, who are compensated to trim trees, modify landscaping, or perform major yard work, and those that perform this type work will be solely responsible for removal and disposal of all materials. The town will not collect yard debris that is generated in conjunction with new construction, remodeling, demolition, or the clearing of trees and brush from properties in preparation for future development of those properties. It is not the intent of the city to collect large portions of trees, entire trees, lot-clearing debris, or multi-family and commercial leaf and yard debris. This material shall not be dumped, thrown, or allowed to remain on any lot or space within the city limits. 
(b)  Penalty for violation. 
(1)  Items found in violation of this section will be tagged as such and written notification shall be given to the property owner, resident, or tenant stating violation and corrective action to be taken. If the violation is not corrected, the city will take action to remedy the violation. The property owner, resident, or tenant may be fined as described below and will be charged the actual costs of cleanup and disposal. 
(2)  Any person in violation of this section shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than $500.00 as permitted by G.S. 14-4 and shall also be subject to appropriate equitable remedies including but not being limited to injunctive relief. The department of development services may stay enforcement of the civil penalty if the offender takes corrective actions within ten days of receipt of notice of violation. Appeals of decisions of the department of development services concerning enforcement of this section may be made to the board of adjustments within ten days of the decision. Appeals to the board of adjustments shall be made in accordance with section 18-334 of this Code. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-40; Amend. of 11-10-2015(1)) 
Cross reference- Vegetation, ch. 32. 
Sec. 24-66. - Refuse on developed or undeveloped property. 
    Whenever refuse accumulates on properties such that it is classified as litter and/or it creates a public nuisance, as determined by the town for public nuisance in article II of chapter 14, then the owner of such property shall be responsible for removing and disposing of the refuse as directed by the town. The enforcement of such removal shall be in accordance with the provisions of the public nuisance ordinance or the litter abatement guidelines contained in section 24-141. If the refuse and limbs and debris cannot be removed by public services in one routine pick-up then it is defined as a nuisance and has to be removed by the violator/property owner. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-41; Amend. of 7-13-2017) 
Sec. 24-67. - Maintenance of authorized residential and recycling containers. 
    It shall be the responsibility of all users of authorized residential containers and recycling containers, if applicable, to ensure that they are maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and in good working order. It shall be the user's responsibility to notify the county or the town; whichever originally provided the container, when repair or replacement is required. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-42) 
Sec. 24-68. - Burning of solid waste prohibited in all areas within the town limits. 
    Burning of solid waste is prohibited in all areas within the town limits; solid waste for this purpose includes, but is not limited to, refuse, recyclable material, white goods, brown goods, leaves, yard debris, yard debris created from lot clearing, cardboard, and all paper goods including newspapers, magazines, books, office paper products, etc. This section is not intended to prohibit or restrict the use of heating and/or cooking devices manufactured and approved for outdoor use when used in accordance with the manufacturers operating guide. Also exempt from these regulations are the following: 
(1)  Homemade cookers, fryers and related devices intended for the preparation of foods. 
a.  Device must be setback a minimum of 15 feet from any structure or ten feet from any property line. 
b.  Device must be properly maintained and kept in a safe and operable condition. 
c.  Device shall be constantly attended during use. 
d.  Pressurized water source, five-gallon bucket of water, or 2A fire extinguisher (minimum size) shall be available for immediate utilization for Class A fires. 
e.  All efforts shall be made to minimize the amount of smoke and odors produced by the device from impending upon neighbor's properties. 
f.  It shall be the responsibility of the property owner or legal tenant to ensure the proper extinguishments of the device. 
(2)  Ground and pit fires used solely for preparation of foods. 
a.  Ground or pit fire areas shall be designed in a manner to restrict spread of fire to surrounding flammable materials, e.g., grasses, weeds, bushes, etc. The use of brick or masonry block surrounding the fire pit is recommended. 
b.  Ground or pit fires shall maintain a setback a minimum of 15 feet from any structure or ten feet from any property line. 
c.  Pressurized water source, five-gallon bucket of water, or 2A fire extinguisher (minimum size) shall be available for immediate utilization for Class A fires. 
d.  Fire shall be constantly attended until the fire is extinguished. 
e.  All efforts shall be made to minimize the amount of smoke and odors produced by the device from impending upon neighbor's properties. 
f.  It shall be the responsibility of the property owner or legal tenant to ensure the proper extinguishments of all fires. 
(3)  Construction sites. Fires used in conjunction with a building site shall be for the purpose of personal warmth only. 
a.  Each construction site is limited to one 55-gallon burning container per site. 
b.  No construction debris, treated lumber or other manufactured products including but not limited to paper, plastic, cardboard shall be burned under any circumstances. 
c.  Pressurized water source, five-gallon bucket of water, or 2A fire extinguisher (minimum size) shall be available for immediate utilization for Class A fires. 
d.  Fire shall be constantly attended until the fire is extinguished. 
e.  All efforts shall be made to minimize the amount of smoke and odors produced by the device from impending upon neighbor's properties. 
f.  Fire container area shall be designed in a manner which will reduce chances of fire spreading to surrounding flammable material, i.e., grasses, weeds, bushes, etc. 
g.  Container shall maintain a setback a minimum of 15 feet from any structure or ten feet from any property line. 
h.  Container shall be covered with a one-half inch or smaller mesh cover at all times. 
i.  It shall be the responsibility of the general contractor to ensure the proper extinguishments of all container fires. 
(4)  Bon fires along the public beach. 
a.  All beach fires shall require a permit from the Oak Island Fire Marshal or his/her designee. Application for permits shall be made in writing stating the purpose of the event, location, time and the name, address and telephone number of the responsible party. 
b.  All beach fires shall maintain a minimum setback of 50 feet from any structure and 25 feet from dune vegetation. 
c.  Pressurized water source, five-gallon bucket of water, or 2A fire extinguisher (minimum size) shall be available for immediate utilization for Class A fires. 
d.  Beach fires must be attended at all times. 
e.  After bon fire has been extinguished, all burned debris must be removed from the burn site and disposed of properly. 
f.  Beach fires shall be prohibited between May 1 to November 15 as to prevent harm to nesting sea turtles. 
g.  Beach fires shall not be larger than four feet by four feet and be no higher than four feet. 
h.  It shall be the responsibility of the permit holder to ensure the proper extinguishments of all fires. 
(5)  Large area control burns. 
a.  Permittable large area control burns are defined as any burn greater than one acre. 
b.  All large area control fires shall require a permit from Oak Island Fire Marshal or his/her designee. Application for permits shall be made in writing stating the purpose of the event, location, time and the name, address and telephone number of the responsible party. 
c.  All large area control fire locations will require a sight evaluation by the fire marshal or his/her designee before approval or denial of the request. 
d.  All large area control fire locations will require a burn plan which shall include, but not be limited to, the following information: 
1.  Address or latitude/longitude of burn location. 
2.  Address of land owner (if different). 
3.  Acres to be burned. 
4.  A list of all fire suppression resources to be on site. 
5.  List of all participating individuals' and/or agencies' contact phone numbers. 
6.  Weather parameters for which the burn will be ignited under, to include at a minimum: 
i.  Wind speed and direction. 
ii.  Temperature minimum/maximum. 
iii.  Relative humidity minimum/maximum. 
iv.  North Carolina Burning Category (1-5). 
v.  Minimum Keetch-Bryam Drought Index (KBDI) (Sunny Point measuring site). 
7.  Map of location showing: 
i.  Burn area. 
ii.  Access/egress roads. 
iii.  Water supply (if applicable). 
iv.  All structures on the property. 
e.  All large area fires shall maintain a minimum setback of 100 feet from any structure. 
f.  Fires must be attended until such time that it is determined that all residual interior smoldering and/or fire is safe to leave unattended by the fire marshal or his designee. The fire marshal or his/her designees may require more than one person in attendance at any given time due to the size and nature of the burn. This will be determined after the sight evaluation. 
g.  Burn areas greater than five acres shall require additional oversight by the state forestry service as well as the town permitting process and will be the responsibly of the land owner to obtain. All burning greater than five acres shall be conducted by a state certified burner(s). 
(6)  Natural debris pile burns for purposes of land clearing. 
a.  "Permittable natural debris pile burns" are defined as any pile of natural grass and/or wood products not defined as a bonfire in subsection (4) of this section or "recreational fire" as defined in the state fire code. 
b.  All natural debris pile fires shall be located on individual lots no less than one acre in size and only product from the same lot will be allowed to be burned. 
c.  All natural debris pile fires shall require a permit from Oak Island Fire Marshal or his/her designee. Application for permits shall be made in writing stating the purpose of the event, location, time and the name, address and telephone number of the responsible party. 
d.  All natural debris pile fire locations will require a sight evaluation by the fire marshal or his/her designee before approval or denial of the request. 
e.  All natural debris pile fire locations will require a burn plan which shall include, but not be limited to, the following information: 
1.  Address or latitude/longitude of burn location. 
2.  Address of Land owner (if different). 
3.  Size of pile to be burned. 
4.  Type of materials to be burned. 
5.  A list of all fire suppression resources to be on site. 
6.  List of all participating individuals and/or agencies contact phone numbers. 
7.  Weather parameters for which the burn will be ignited under, to include at a minimum: 
i.  Wind speed and direction. 
ii.  Temperature minimum/maximum. 
iii.  Relative humidity minimum/maximum. 
iv.  North Carolina Burning Category (1-5). 
v.  Minimum KBDI (Sunny Point measuring [site]). 
8.  Map of location showing: 
i.  Burn location. 
ii.  Access/egress roads. 
iii.  Water supply (if applicable). 
iv.  All structures on the property. 
f.  All natural debris pile fires shall maintain a minimum setback of 500 feet from any structure. 
g.  All natural debris pile fires shall maintain a minimum setback of 250 feet from any public road. 
h.  Fires must be attended until such time that it is determined that all residual interior smoldering and/or fire is safe to leave unattended by the fire marshal or his designee. The fire marshal or his/her designees may require more than one person in attendance at any given time due to the size and nature of the burn. This will be determined after the sight evaluation. 
i.  It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to adhere to any additional requirement set forth by North Carolina Division of Air Quality where applicable. 
(7)  Burning permits. 
a.  Where required, all burning permits will be obtained through Oak Island Fire Department on a schedule set by the department. 
b.  All permits will be for a period not to exceed 24 hours. 
c.  Permits will be issued for a period not exceeding three days from the time of application. 
d.  All open burning is subject to compliancy with North Carolina Fire Prevention Codes, North Carolina Forestry regulations, and North Carolina Division of Air Quality. 
e.  All burning permits may be revoked at any time by Town of Oak Island Emergency Services personnel (fire, rescue, police or code enforcement officer) due to weather conditions, unsafe practices, permit violations, situation that creates or adds to a hazardous or objectionable situation. 
f.  During periods where "BURNING" bans, "No Burn Days," or "Red Flag Warning" have been placed due to weather conditions, no burning permits will be given and all previously obtained burning permits will be revoked until such time the fire hazard has decreased to a safe range. 
g.  Permit applicants must be at least 18 years of age. There must be at least one person on site of the fire 18 years of age or greater during the burn. 
(8)  Sky lanterns. 
a.  "Sky lantern" defined. As used in this chapter, the term "sky lantern" means any sky lantern, Kongming lantern, Chinese lantern, wish lantern, flying lantern, sky candle, fire balloon, and other lanterns airborne in nature made of paper or other combustible material with a wood, wire, or plastic frame containing a candle, fuel cell composed of waxy flammable material or other open flame which serves as a heat source to heat the air inside the device to cause it to lift into the air. 
b.  It is unlawful for any person to sell, use, transfer, discharge or ignite any sky lantern within the town or to cause a lighted sky lantern to float into the town. 
(9)  Fire department training exercises. 
a.  Fire department training shall be conducted in accordance with NFPA (National Fire Protection Association) Standards 1001 "Standards for Professional Firefighters" and 1403 "Standards for Live Fire Exercises." 
b.  All training burns shall comply with the Environmental Protection Agency, Air Quality and Asbestos inspection and removal guidelines. Costs for sampling and testing shall be the responsibility of the fire department. All associated costs for asbestos removal shall be the responsibility of the property owner. 
c.  Owner(s) of the property given to the fire department for live fire training exercises shall fill out and have notarized the proper paperwork granting the fire department permission to destroy said property and acknowledging that no insurance claim will be made on said property. 
d.  Owner(s) shall be charged a fee of one-half of the quote for demolition, removal and disposal of debris, as submitted by an approved general contractor. 
e.  The fire department shall mail a notice by first class mail to all property owners within 100 feet of the subject property specifying the date, time, and location of the exercise. This shall be done no less than 14 days prior to a live fire training exercise. It is the responsibility of the property owner to notify legal tenants. 
f.  It shall be the responsibility of the fire department to ensure the proper extinguishments of all fires. 
g.  It shall be the responsibility of the fire department to ensure that the property is cleaned and cleared of all debris following the fire not prior to seven days (to allow for the cooling down of coals and embers), but no later than 21 days. This expense shall be the responsibility of the fire department. 
    To protect public health and safety, any fire permitted by this section shall be immediately extinguished upon the direction of any officer of the town duly charged with enforcement of this provision. 
    This section to allow burning under special circumstances shall not be applicable when a burning ban has been issues by the state, county or local governmental unit. 
    This section to allow burning under special circumstances shall not be applicable when the winds are more than 15 miles per hour sustained. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-43; Amend. of 12-13-2005(2); Amend. of 10-18-2007; Amend. of 7-9-2013; Amend. of 4-8-2014(3); Amend. of 6-9-2015(1); Amend. of 2-15-2016(1)) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 16. 
Sec. 24-69. - Cart racks and collection. 
    It is the intent of the town that all 90-gallon containers be secured in such a manner either next to non-elevated or underneath elevated houses, except on collection days when they are to be placed at curbside, so that the town street right-of-way remains clear of empty containers, and so that containers are not damaged or overturned by high winds or other occurrences. A previously approved alternate storage arrangement is as follows: A sturdy, wooden three-sided rack of sufficient size to just hold the required container(s) may be constructed by the owner, on their property, in accordance with town specifications. The rack shall be maintained in a sound and presentable condition or be removed. Effective October 1, 2014, installation of new racks will not be permitted, unless the preexisting cart rack is being replaced. Cart racks are permissible within the front, rear, and side yard setbacks and are not considered an accessory structure. Cart racks shall not be within a six-foot radius of a utility infrastructure point or obstructing an easement. All carts must be placed in the right-of-way, approximately five feet from the edge of pavement no earlier than 2:00 p.m. the day prior to collection, and at least by 6:00 a.m. on the scheduled day of collection, and pulled back to the house or returned to the cart rack by 7:00 p.m. the following day after collection. 
(Amend. of 10-18-2007; Ord. of 2-19-2008; Amend. of 8-12-2014; Amend. of 7-13-2017) 
Editor's note- An amendment of Aug. 12, 2014, amended § 24-69 in its entirety, including section catchline. Section 24-69 was formerly titled "Cart racks." 
Sec. 24-70. - Household waste collection facilities. 
    The town may provide central collection facilities for household waste. 
(1)  If central collection facilities are made available, the town shall publish specific instructions for the use of such facilities, and it shall be the responsibility of all individuals to properly use the facilities and only deposit approved items at such facilities in accordance with the town's instructions. Failure to follow the town's instructions by placing unauthorized materials at such facilities shall constitute unlawful littering and be subject to appropriate enforcement as described in this chapter. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2017) 
Secs. 24-71-24-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL REFUSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 10. 

Sec. 24-91. - Scope of division. 
    This division shall apply to commercial and industrial generated refuse. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-56) 
Sec. 24-92. - Enforcement of division provisions. 
    This division shall be enforced by the town either by civil proceedings or by removing and disposing of litter according to the provisions and procedures for abatement of litter as provided in this chapter and as prescribed by G.S. 160A-174, 160A-175, 160A-192, 160A-193, and 160A-303.1, including the provisions for notice and hearings provided or referred to therein, or according to the provisions contained for public nuisance in article II of chapter 14. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-57; Ord. of 2-12-2002, § 10-57) 
Sec. 24-93. - Collection for commercial and industrial refuse. 
(a)  No person or business shall place or cause to be placed any loose refuse on the ground or allow refuse to accumulate beside buildings. 
(b)  All commercial business or industrial establishments shall use bulk refuse containers, authorized residential containers, and/or authorized plastic bag containers if such are available, or any combination thereof, to properly contain the volume of refuse generated by such business or industrial establishment during any collection period. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner or other responsible party of a commercial business or industrial establishment to purchase, rent or otherwise arrange for, through the county and/or the town, the refuse containers they will need. 
(d)  Whenever refuse accumulates on commercial or industrial properties such that it is classified as litter and/or it creates a public nuisance, as determined by the town in accordance with the town provisions of public nuisance in article II of chapter 14, then the owner or other responsible party of such property shall be responsible for removing and disposing of the refuse as directed by the town. The enforcement of such removal shall be in accordance with the provisions for public nuisance in article II of chapter 14, or the litter abatement guidelines contained in section 24-141. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-58) 
Sec. 24-94. - Collection frequency. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the owner or other responsible party of a commercial business or industrial establishment to arrange for a collection frequency for their refuse containers that is sufficient to ensure proper and complete containment of all the refuse they generate during any collection period. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-59) 
Sec. 24-95. - Bulk refuse container. 
(a)  All bulk containers shall be located on the commercial or industrial property that is using the container. No bulk containers shall be allowed on or within the town's right-of-way. 
(b)  The commercial or industrial property owner shall provide marl or paved access areas to bulk containers. 
(c)  All bulk containers shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition and in good working order. It shall be the user's responsibility to ensure that repairs or replacement of containers are completed as necessary. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-60) 
Secs. 24-96-24-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HEALTH AND SANITATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 4; environment, ch. 14; flood damage prevention, § 18-541 et seq.; utilities, ch. 30. 

Sec. 24-131. - Enforcement of article provisions. 
    This article shall be enforced by the town either by civil proceedings or by removing and disposing of litter according to the provisions and procedures for abatement of litter as provided in section 24-141 and as prescribed by G.S. 160A-174, 160A-175, 160A-192, 160A-193, and 160A-303.1, including the provisions for notice and hearings provided or referred to therein, or according to the provisions contained for public nuisance in article II of chapter 14. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-81; Ord. of 2-12-2002, § 10-81) 
Sec. 24-132. - Presumptions. 
(a)  When refuse is swept, thrown or deposited into, upon or along any private property in violation of this article, the owner, tenant, lessee, proprietor or other person in charge thereof, after reasonable written notification, shall be presumed to have committed or consented to the commission of such offense. 
(b)  When refuse is swept, thrown or deposited into, upon or along any public property in violation of this article, the owner, occupant, tenant, lessee, proprietor or other person adjacent to the public property, after reasonable written notification, shall be presumed to have committed or consented to the commission of such offense. 
(c)  When refuse is so blown, scattered, spilled, thrown or placed from a vehicle, the operator thereof shall be presumed to have committed such offense. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-82) 
Sec. 24-133. - Depositing of refuse prohibited; littering not allowed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep, throw, deposit, or to permit, allow, maintain or contribute to the sweeping, throwing or depositing of any refuse into, upon or along a drain, gutter, street, sidewalk, alley, vacant or occupied lot, walk, parking lot, embankment, or upon any public or private premises within the town. However, nothing in this section shall prevent the placing of refuse in a designated location for removal by the county or town or other refuse collector. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-83; Ord. of 3-12-2002, § 10-83) 
Sec. 24-134. - Duty of owners with respect to refuse. 
    The owners, occupants and lessees of all property, jointly and severally, are required to control all refuse, placing such refuse in proper containers and/or arranging for collection or other disposal disposition in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Owners, occupant, lessees within the (CB) community business, (C-LD) commercial low density, and (CR) commercial recreation districts are required to remove the refuse/recycle containers from the curb side or designated collection area within 24 hours of their regularly scheduled collection date. Persons responsible for parking lots, shopping centers, convenience stores, drive-in restaurants and all other commercial and industrial enterprises shall keep their respective properties free of uncontrolled refuse, i.e., litter, including all vacant areas, borders, parking areas, embankments, fences and walls thereon. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-84; Amend. of 6-12-2012) 
Sec. 24-135. - Providing containers for refuse generated by premises. 
    Every owner, occupant, tenant and lessee using or occupying any commercial, institutional or industrial building or property shall be obligated, jointly and severally, to provide adequate containers to hold the refuse generated by operations on the premises. Specifically, the requirement for such containers shall apply to shopping centers, supermarkets, convenience stores, fast-food restaurants, service stations and similar establishments, and shall likewise apply to all other commercial establishments, garages, schools, colleges and churches. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-85) 
Sec. 24-136. - Duty to ensure cleanliness of areas surrounding businesses. 
    The proprietor and person in charge of every business and commercial establishment in the town, jointly and severally, are hereby required to keep the driveways, yards, parking lots and areas adjacent thereto and under their control clean at all times and to place refuse and sweepings in a container to prevent rescattering. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-86) 
Sec. 24-137. - Parking lot owners to provide containers. 
    Every owner and every operator of a private, commercial, industrial or institutional parking lot shall provide adequate containers to hold the refuse generated by the operation or use of such parking lot. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-87) 
Sec. 24-138. - Refuse storage areas to be kept clean. 
    Every owner, occupant and lessee of a house or other building shall be jointly and severally required to maintain refuse storage areas in a clean condition and to ensure that all refuse is properly containerized when stored therein. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-88) 
Sec. 24-139. - Construction site to be maintained. 
    Property owners and prime contractors in charge of a construction site are jointly and severally required to take appropriate measures to ensure the control of C&D and other refuse created by the construction and related activities. These measures may include, but are not limited to, providing a fenced-in area, a trailer, a truck or a dumpster to contain such refuse and prevent the creation of litter on or adjacent to the construction site. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-89) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8. 
Sec. 24-140. - Transporting of refuse regulated. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to transport any refuse or other cargo upon the public streets in the town if the refuse or cargo is of a character or substance which is likely to be deposited from the vehicle onto the right-of-way and become litter, unless such refuse or cargo is secured by containers, tarpaulin or other device which shall effectively prevent such deposit on the right-of-way. 
(b)  The duties and responsibilities imposed in this section shall be applicable alike to the owner of a vehicle, the operator thereof, and the owner or operator from whose private premise or business establishment the refuse or other cargo originated. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-90) 
Cross reference- Traffic, ch. 28. 
Sec. 24-141. - Notice to abate littering. 
(a)  Whenever litter is found to exist within the town, the litter can be declared a public nuisance and corrective action sought for public nuisance in article II of chapter 14, or the town manager or his designee may exercise the provisions contained in this section by providing a written notice to abate to the owner and/or occupant of the property upon which such litter exists, or upon the person causing, permitting, maintaining or continuing the litter. 
(b)  The notice to abate the litter issued under the provisions of this article shall contain the following: 
(1)  The location of the litter; 
(2)  A description of what constitutes the litter; 
(3)  A statement of facts necessary to abate the litter; 
(4)  An order to abate the litter; 
(5)  A statement that such person may request a hearing, within ten working days; and 
(6)  A statement that, if the litter is not abated as directed and no request for a hearing is made within the prescribed time, the town may abate such litter and assess the cost thereof against such person. 
(c)  Should the party receiving a notice to abate fail to abate pursuant to the provisions of this article, the town shall proceed to abate such litter and shall prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof. 
(d)  Any and all costs incurred by the town in abatement of litter per the provision of this article shall constitute a lien against the property upon which such litter existed, and such lien shall be filed with the tax collector and collected in the same manner as provided for the collection of ad valorem taxes. Such lien shall be notice to all persons from the time of its filing with the tax administrator and shall bear interest at the legal rate thereafter until satisfied. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-91) 
Secs. 24-142-24-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES 

Sec. 24-171. - Enforcement of article provisions. 
    This article shall be enforced by the town either by civil proceedings or by removing and disposing of litter according to the provisions and procedures for abatement of litter as provided in this chapter and as prescribed by G.S. 160A-174, 160A-175, 160A-192, 160A-193, and 160A-303.1, including the provisions for notice and hearings provided or referred to therein, or according to the provisions contained for public nuisance in article II of chapter 14. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-111; Ord. of 2-12-2002, § 10-111) 
Sec. 24-172. - Commercial and noncommercial handbills. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbills on vehicles or vacant premises unless such handbill is secured in such a manner as to not become litter. Handbills may be distributed on occupied premises, provided that there is no objection by the owner or authorized occupant of the premises and the bills are placed or deposited in a manner so as to prevent the handbills from blowing or drifting onto public or private property. The unauthorized distribution of handbills shall be considered as litter and subject to abatement as described in section 24-141. 
(b)  Mailboxes may not be used except in accordance with federal postal laws and regulations. 
(c)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States Postal Service. The provisions of this article shall also not apply to the delivery of newspapers, with the exception that newspapers shall be delivered in such a manner as to prevent their being scattered by the elements. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-112) 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 10. 
Sec. 24-173. - Abandonment of refrigerators and other airtight containers in places accessible to children. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or within any unoccupied or abandoned building, dwelling or other structure under his control, or in any other place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended, or discarded icebox, refrigerator or other container which has an airtight door or lid and a locking device which may not be released from the inside, without first removing the door, lid or locking device from such icebox, refrigerator or container or otherwise eliminating any possibility of access by children. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-113) 
Sec. 24-174. - Posting notices. 
    No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device calculated to attract the attention of the public to any lampposts, traffic control devices, streets, trees, or any other public property in the right-of-way or upon any public structure or building, except as may be authorized or required by law. The unauthorized posting or affixing thereof shall be considered as litter and subject to abatement. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-114) 
Sec. 24-175. - Depositing refuse in estuarine or marsh areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit refuse of any type in the channel or any branch of the waters of the state; or estuarine and marsh areas adjacent thereto, or on the banks thereof. The unauthorized depositing of refuse may be designated as litter or declared a public nuisance and be subject to abatement as appropriate. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-115) 
Sec. 24-176. - Filling land with offensive material; burying materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bury or use for fill or dump upon any land within the town limits any refuse including C&D, garbage, dead animals, decayed vegetable or animal matter, or any other offensive material. All such material shall be collected and disposed of as otherwise stipulated within this chapter. The unauthorized use of refuse as fill or dumping thereof may be designated as litter or declared a public nuisance and be subject to abatement as appropriate. The filling, etc., of all areas of environmental concern (AEC) shall be controlled by state or federal regulations. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-116) 
Sec. 24-177. - Depositing refuse on the beach. 
    No person shall throw or deposit refuse onto the beach, from a pier or from a boat that will cause such refuse to wash ashore onto any shoreline within the town limits. Where refuse containers are not provided, all refuse shall be carried away from the beach, pier or boat by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere. The unauthorized depositing of refuse may be designated as litter or declared a public nuisance and be subject to abatement as appropriate. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-117) 
Sec. 24-178. - Clearing of debris after vehicle accidents. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the towing company designated to remove a wrecked vehicle to clean up the highway, road, and/or right-of-way after an accident involving a wrecked vehicle. 
(Ord. of 11-14-2000(1), § 10-118) 
Sec. 24-179. - Littering fine. 
    The fine for littering as defined by this chapter shall be $250.00 for the first occurrence and $500.00 for each occurrence thereafter. 
(Amend. of 3-8-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. of March 8, 2011 did not specify manner of inclusion. Hence, to facilitate indexing, said provisions have been included as § 24-179. 
Chapter 25 - SPECIAL EVENTS 

Sec. 25-1. - Application of regulations. 
    This chapter applies to all street fairs, festivals, carnivals, parades, marches, rallies, demonstrations, and other activities or public events that require the temporary closing or obstruction of all or a portion of any street or other public right-of-way or that substantially hinders or prevents the normal flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic along any street or other public right-of-way. Any such activity covered by this chapter shall hereafter be referred to as "the event." 
(Ord. of 2-8-2011) 
Sec. 25-2. - Permit required. 
    No person may run, operate, or sponsor any event in any public street or right-of-way without a permit obtained from the town manager in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2011) 
Cross reference- General penalty, § 1-7. 
Sec. 25-3. - Permit application. 
    Applications for the permit authorized by this chapter shall be submitted on a form provided by the town manager and shall contain the following information: 
(a)  Name, address, and telephone number of the person, organization or entity seeking to conduct or sponsor the event. 
(b)  Name, address, and telephone number of the individual in charge of the event. 
(c)  The proposed date and time period when the event will be conducted. 
(d)  A sketch-map showing: 
(1)  The area where the event is to take place. 
(2)  Any streets to be closed or obstructed. 
(3)  Any barriers or traffic-control devices that will be erected. 
(4)  The location of any concession stand, booth, or other temporary structures or facilities. 
(5)  The location of proposed fences, stand, platforms, benches, or bleachers. 
(e)  The approximate number of people expected to attend the event. 
(f)  When applicable, a request that the town provide specified services and/or that the town close identified streets or portions of streets for a particular period. 
(g)  Sufficient proof of liability insurance in accordance with section 25-5 of this chapter. 
(h)  Any other information determined by the town manager to be necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2011) 
Sec. 25-4. - Staff review. 
    Upon receipt of the permit application, the town manager shall circulate it to the police chief, the fire chief, the public services director, and other appropriate persons for their comments. The manager may arrange to have a conference on the application with the applicant and one or more department heads. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2011) 
Sec. 25-5. - Insurance requirement. 
    The town manager may require as a condition precedent or subsequent to issuance of the permit that the applicant obtain a comprehensive general liability insurance policy or comparable special events liability business in this state with coverage that includes the entire area of the event. If such a policy is required, the town shall be named as an additional insured on the policy. The policy limits of such insurance shall be not less than: 
Property damage: $1,000,000.00 for each occurrence Bodily injury or death: $100,000.00 for each person 
$2,000,000.00 for each occurrence.  
(Ord. of 2-8-2011) 
Sec. 25-6. - Fees; costs incurred by town. 
(a)  The applicant for a permit under sections 25-2 and 25-3 of this chapter, if such permit is for a parade, activity or public event (hereafter referred to as "event") which requires the temporary closing or obstruction of all or a portion of any street, shall, prior to the issuance of a permit, pay a fee in the following amount, as applicable, unless such fee is partially or fully waived by the town council in accordance with this section: 
(1)  An event sponsored by the town, such as the Christmas parade, or any other event designated by the town council as one that is sponsored by the town: No fee; 
(2)  An event not sponsored by the town, which requires the temporary closing or obstruction of all or a portion of any street for less than one hour: Per town fee schedule; 
(3)  An event not sponsored by the town, which requires the temporary closing or obstruction of all or a portion of any street for one hour or more: Per town fee schedule. 
(b)  The fees imposed by subsection (a) of this section may be partly or wholly waived by action of the town council. In waiving such fees in part or in full, the town council may consider, among others, the following factors: 
(1)  The capacity of the event sponsor to defray the costs of the fee through admission fees, participation fees, advertising fees and/or sponsorship contributions; 
(2)  The number of people the event is likely to bring into the town and the expected economic impact of the event on the town and town merchants; 
(3)  The possible and expected impact of the event upon the town's image and reputation; 
(4)  Any features of the event which will either reduce or increase the normal expenditures of services and equipment which the town must utilize in connection with the event; and 
(5)  Such other factor as the town council may determine justifies the town's bearing of a portion or the full costs of the extraordinary services or equipment necessitated by the event. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2011) 
Sec. 25-7. - Standards for issuance of permit. 
(a)  The town manager shall issue the permit authorizing the event unless he finds that: 
(1)  Conduct of the event will require the assignment of so many police officers that the remainder of the town cannot adequately be protected; 
(2)  The event will interfere with the movement of emergency vehicles to such an extent that adequate police, fire, or other emergency services cannot be provided throughout the town; 
(3)  The applicant has failed to obtain any necessary permits or licenses, including any required building permit or privilege license, or the applicant is otherwise in violation of any town ordinance; or 
(4)  The event will work a severe hardship on persons occupying property adjacent to the site, location, or route of the event as a result of the denial of access to property or for other substantial reasons; 
(5)  The event, if held at the time or at the location or along the route proposed, will cause an unreasonable and unwarranted disruption to vehicular or pedestrian traffic; or 
(6)  The applicant has failed to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter, including the payment of any fees required. 
(b)  If a permit is issued in accordance with [subsection] (a) of this section, the town manager may attach to it any reasonable conditions. 
(c)  If the town manager finds that he/she cannot issue the permit for reasons specified in [subsection] (a) of this section, he/she may request the applicant to modify its application to remove any objections to the issuance of the permit, and the applicant may do so without further notice or hearing. 
(d)  Any event conducted pursuant to a permit issued under this section shall be conducted strictly in accordance with the terms of the permit, including any conditions attached hereto. 
(e)  If the town manager denies or revokes a parade permit, this action shall be final unless the applicant or permittee shall, within two days after the receipt of notice of the denial or revocation, file with the town manager written appeal. The town manager shall, within 24 hours after the appeal is filed, consider all evidence in support of or against the action appealed and render a decision either sustaining or reversing the denial or revocation. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2011) 
Sec. 25-8. - Street closing. 
(a)  If the town manager finds that the permit should be issued and that, to conduct the event, it is necessary to close a street or to reroute traffic, the town council may pass a resolution authorizing this to be done. No such resolution shall be passed affecting streets that are part of the state street system without the approval of the state department of transportation. 
(b)  The resolution shall identify the street or portion thereof to be affected and shall indicate the date and time when the street or portion thereof is to be closed or traffic thereon is to be limited in some way. The resolution shall also direct the manager to have appropriate traffic-control devices installed to give notice of the temporary traffic controls. 
(c)  No person may operate any vehicle contrary to the traffic-control devices installed in accordance with [subsection] (b) of this section. 
(d)  The town manager shall, by any adequate means, notify persons occupying property abutting the street where the event is to take place of the contents of any resolution passed in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2011) 
Sec. 25-9. - Sponsor responsible for cleanup. 
    The sponsor of the event shall be responsible for cleaning up any litter caused by the event, removing all temporary obstructions, and in general returning the area where the event takes place to the condition that existed prior to the event. The town manager may require the sponsor to post a bond or other sufficient security to guarantee compliance with this section. 
(Ord. of 2-8-2011) 
Chapter 26 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance providing for public improvements and assessments saved from repeal, § 1-8(a)(2); any ordinance relating to the status of specific streets or the names or prefixes of streets saved from repeal, § 1-8(a)(8); any ordinance relating to no parking areas, speed limits, stop intersections, one-way streets, or through streets saved from repeal, § 1-8(a)(10); aviation, ch. 6; buildings and building regulations, ch. 8; use of public right-of-way for filming, § 10-182; environment, ch. 14; land use development, ch. 18; zoning, § 18-31 et seq.; off-street parking, § 18-141 et seq.; driveways and curb cuts, § 18-171 et seq.; signs, § 18-251 et seq.; subdivision regulations, § 18-371 et seq.; land suitability, required improvements, and minimum standards of design for streets in subdivisions, § 18-446; land suitability, required improvements, and minimum standards of design for streetlights in subdivisions, § 18-449; flood damage prevention, § 18-541 et seq.; parks and recreation, ch. 22; development and operation of parks and street ends, § 22-6; traffic, ch. 28; parking on or obstructing sidewalks, § 28-9; utilities, ch. 30; vegetation, ch. 32. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate the streets and sidewalks, G.S. 160A-296. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Construction or other improvements within street rights-of-way. 
(a)  No person or entity, other than the town, shall construct, install, maintain or erect any utility infrastructure, structure, pole, fence or other obstruction in any town street right-of-way without having first fully executed a right-of-way encroachment agreement with the town. The following exceptions to the foregoing shall apply: 
(1)  Mailboxes; 
(2)  Newspaper boxes; and 
(3)  Driveway connections, utility service laterals and stormwater cross drainage piping installed and/or constructed in accordance with town specification. 
(b)  Except as provided in (a)(1) through (3) above, no person or entity, other than the town or NCDOT, shall construct, maintain or erect any structure, pole, fence or other obstruction within any street right-of-way located, either now or in the future, within the corporate limits of Oak Island that is a part of the state roadway system without having first fully executed a right-of-way encroachment agreement with NCDOT. 
(c)  Within any municipal or state street right-of-way, the town, or its designee, shall be responsible for repairing or replacing, to equal or better condition, any driveway, stormwater cross drainage piping or walkway within the street right-of-way that is damaged or destroyed by any project, improvements or repair work undertaken or contracted by the town within such rights-of-way. 
(d)  Property owners shall be permitted to undertake seeding of lawn or other nonstructural improvements and shall be obligated to properly maintain same in the area between the street pavement edge or edge of the traveled way and the property line/right-of-way line, provided such work does not prevent or hinder the allowance of on street parking where such parking is not otherwise prohibited by this Code. Property owners undertaking such improvements shall be responsible for any damage to such improvements that might occur during the course of infrastructure improvements occurring within street rights-of-way by or on behalf of the town or NCDOT. 
(e)  The provisions of this article shall be subject to enforcement through initiation by the town of criminal or civil proceedings or any other remedy available as provided for under G.S. 160A-175. 
(Ord. of 4-10-2001(2), § 1; Ord. of 2-10-2004; Amend. of 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 26-2. - Street lighting placement. 
    Street lighting shall be placed according to the following criteria: 
(1)  Streetlights shall be placed at street intersections, and at road curves where vehicle forward visibility distance is limited or other such unique locations where the safety of vehicle traffic and pedestrians might dictate their need, as determined by the town manager and the public works director. 
(2)  Streetlights shall not be placed for residential or commercial property security, area aesthetics, or any other such reasons unless specifically authorized by the town council on a case-by-case basis. 
(3)  New streetlight installations shall be in accordance with the criteria of subsections (1) and (2) of this section, and any existing streetlights not in compliance with the criteria of subsections (1) and (2) of this section as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall be removed, or relocated to meet the criteria, as soon as feasible. 
(Ord. of 9-11-2001(2), § 1) 
Secs. 26-3-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UNDERGROUND UTILITY EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Underground Damage Prevention Act, G.S. 87-101 et seq. 

Sec. 26-31. - Purpose and intent of article. 
(a)  In the recent past, there have been numerous incidents where persons or contractors undertaking excavation activities in or near public rights-of-way and utility lines have damaged underground utilities due to negligent or willful acts or omissions. 
(b)  The Underground Damage Prevention Act, G.S. 87-101 et seq., requires certain notice to utility owners by persons performing excavation activities. In addition, G.S. 87-104 imposes standards on excavations performed after appropriate notice to utility owners. In some instances, damage to underground utilities has resulted from a failure to comply with the provisions of the Underground Damage Prevention Act. 
(c)  The town is authorized by G.S. 160A-174 to adopt ordinances defining, prohibiting, regulating or abating acts, omissions, or conditions, detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare of its citizens. In addition, the town is authorized by G.S. 160A-296 to regulate digging in streets, sidewalks or alleys. 
(d)  It is in the interest of the general public health, safety and welfare to adopt an ordinance imposing certain standards on excavations in the vicinity of underground utilities and imposing civil penalties for the violation thereof. 
(Ord. of 12-14-1999(1)) 
Sec. 26-32. - Excavations affecting underground utilities. 
(a)  The definitions set out in G.S. 87-101 are hereby adopted as a part of this section. 
(b)  No person shall undertake or make an excavation in any highway, public space or private easement of a utility owner in such a manner as to endanger, injure or damage any underground utility. For the purposes of this section, the failure to comply with G.S. 87-102 and G.S. 87-104 shall be considered endangerment of underground utilities. 
(c)  Any person excavating in any highway, public space or private easement of a utility owner shall take reasonable steps to protect any underground utility lines when excavating within 30 inches of either side of the outside edges of the marked location of a utility owner's underground utility as referenced in G.S. 87-101(5). This protection shall include hand-digging, air-jetting or vacuum excavation, or other means of safe excavation designed to avoid damage to the utility marked until the utility is exposed or is determined to be below the proposed excavation. Where a proposed excavation lies adjacent and/or parallel to an existing utility and within or partially within the tolerance zone, the existing utility shall be exposed by the methods in this subsection prior to beginning the excavation. Once the utility is exposed and the location markings are found to be correct, the excavation may proceed with mechanized equipment. 
(d)  Any person may assert as an affirmative defense to a violation of this section that a utility owner failed to identify the location of an underground utility after being notified in accordance with G.S. 87-102, or a utility owner otherwise failed to properly locate an underground utility after being so notified. 
(Ord. of 12-14-1999(1), § 1) 
Sec. 26-33. - Penalties and remedies for violation of article. 
(a)  In addition to the responsibility for payment of time and material costs for the repair of damages, a violation of the provisions of section 26-32 shall subject the offender to the following civil penalties: 
(1)  When the violation involves a public water or sewer utility line: 
a.  For a first violation, $250.00; 
b.  For a second violation, $500.00; and 
c.  For a third and any subsequent violation, $1,000.00. 
(2)  Each day that a violation continues after the offender has been notified of the violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the town may seek to enforce this article through any appropriate equitable action authorized by law. 
(Ord. of 12-14-1999(1), § 2) 
Secs. 26-34-26-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING NUMBERING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 8. 

Sec. 26-61. - Generally. 
(a)  The town lot numbering/street address system will be maintained and updated as necessary by the department of development services. An updated copy of the system will be kept on file in the office of the town clerk. 
(b)  The department of development services shall be responsible for designating the proper lot number for the street address for any new dwelling, commercial building, or open air market. 
(c)  Such street address/house number shall be at least three inches in height, and shall be posted in plain view on each dwelling, commercial building, or open air market facing the nearest street so as to facilitate the location of the dwelling, commercial building, or open air market in the event of 911 emergency calls. For oceanfront structures, such information shall also be posted on the oceanfront side of the structure. Street address/house numbers on the oceanfront façade shall be a minimum of six inches in height, shall indicate the property address as to West or East of Middleton with an "E" or "W" and shall be placed as high as feasibly possible for visibility purposes from the public beach strand. For those oceanfront properties along Ocean Drive only six-inch numbers shall be required. Pre-existing oceanfront structures shall comply with the requirements of this section within 90 days from receipt of the second notice of violation. Failure to comply shall result in a fine or legal action as set forth in section 26-63. 
(d)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the dwelling, commercial building, or open air market to display the street address or house number. A certificate of occupancy will not be issued for new construction until the proper street address/house number has been displayed. 
(Ord. of 4-10-2001(1), § 1; Ord. of 5-9-2006(2); Amend. of 4-10-2007(2); Amend. of 11-12-2014(1)) 
Sec. 26-62. - Unlawful to deface street address or house number. 
    It shall be unlawful to alter, deface or take down any street address or house number that has been placed on any property in accordance with this article, except for repair or replacement of such number. 
(Ord. of 4-10-2001(1), § 2; Amend. of 4-10-2007(2)) 
Sec. 26-63. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    A violation of the provisions of this article shall subject the offender to a civil penalty payable to the town. Fees for the civil citation are spelled out in the Oak Island Fee Schedule and are subject to be updated from time to time. Failure to pay the civil penalty shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable as provided by section 1-7. 
(Ord. of 4-10-2001(1), § 3; Amend. of 6-10-2003; Amend. of 4-10-2007(2)) 
Chapter 27 - RESERVED 
Chapter 28 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic control for filming, § 10-178; junk vehicles, § 14-91 et seq.; establishment of motor vehicle routes for vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents, § 16-6; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 20; transporting of refuse regulated, § 24-140; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles, G.S. ch. 20; powers of local authorities, G.S. 20-169; traffic control by municipalities, G.S. 160A-300 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- An ordinance adopted Oct. 7, 2014, amended the Code by the addition of regulations pertaining to the operation of golf carts. Inasmuch as said regulations were incorporated as an article in ch. 28, §§ 28-1-28-12, heretofore comprising the entirety of ch. 28, have been redesignated art. I for purposes of maintaining Code format. 

Sec. 28-1. - Traffic control signs and devices. 
(a)  The town shall adopt and designate locations for stop signs, yield signs, speed limit signs, one-way streets and other traffic control signs and devices as the town council deems appropriate and necessary. A schedule of one-way streets and other locations for traffic control devices will be maintained and available for inspection at the town hall offices. 
(b)  Enforcement of each traffic control sign or device shall be the duty of the police department. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2000(3), § 1(a); Amend. of 1-12-2005) 
Sec. 28-2. - Stop when traffic obstructed. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection, or a marked crosswalk, unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles, or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2000(3), § 1(b); Amend. of 1-12-2005) 
Sec. 28-3. - Limitations on backing. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not back the vehicle into any intersection or over a crosswalk, and he shall not in any event, or any place, back a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety, and he shall give ample warning to those who may be behind, by hand and horn or other signal. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2000(3), § 1(c); Amend. of 1-12-2005) 
Sec. 28-4. - Clinging to moving vehicles. 
    Any person riding upon any bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle shall not attach such bicycle, motorcycle, coaster, etc., or himself, to any moving vehicle upon the roadway. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2000(3), § 1(d); Amend. of 1-12-2005) 
Sec. 28-5. - Restricted areas designated; exceptions. 
    No person shall operate any motor vehicle on the beach strand facing the Atlantic Ocean and Lockwood Folly Inlet or the sand dunes within the town limits. Exceptions: police car, fire truck, emergency rescue equipment or other official vehicles in the performance of their duties. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2000(3), § 1(e); Amend. of 1-12-2005) 
Sec. 28-6. - Exception for motorized wheelchairs. 
    Notwithstanding the restricted areas listed in section 28-5, person(s) who have been issued a state handicapped permit and/or a permanent handicapped registration plate and a permit issued by the town police department may operate an approved beach accessible vehicle on the beach in designated areas. Operation is permitted by the permit holder or his/her designated driver who shall at all times operate in a safe and prudent manner, who shall give way to pedestrians at all times and who shall give warning before starting, stopping, turning his vehicle and remain clear of the federally-protected turtle nesting areas. The number of passengers shall be limited to the design of the approved vehicle. 
    Operation is limited to: 
(1)  The last beach access on West Beach Drive and west to a point as designated by signage reflecting no further vehicle traffic; 
(2)  From 58th Street SE to 69th Street SE; 
(3)  From dawn to dusk. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2000(3), § 1(e); Amend. of 1-12-2005; Amend. of 2-8-2005) 
Sec. 28-7. - Avoiding traffic control devices. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle at any time with the intent to avoid an official traffic control device. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2000(3), § 1(f); Amend. of 1-12-2005) 
Sec. 28-8. - Riding on part of vehicle other than designated passenger area. 
    It shall be unlawful to occupy a portion of a motor vehicle not intended for passenger use by riding in or on a part of such motor vehicle in any place other than the designated passenger area including, but not limited to, sitting on the trunk of a convertible, riding on the hood or bumpers of vehicles and riding outside the bed area of a pickup truck. 
(a)  The operator of a vehicle having an open bed or open cargo area shall ensure that no child under 16 years of age is transported in the bed or cargo area of that vehicle. An open bed or open cargo area is a bed or cargo area without permanent overhead restraining construction. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section does not apply in any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  An adult is present in the bed or cargo area of the vehicle and is supervising the child. 
(2)  The child is secured or restrained by a seat belt manufactured in compliance with Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard No. 208, installed to support a load strength of not less than 5,000 pounds for each belt, and of a type approved by the commissioner. 
(3)  An emergency situation exists. 
(4)  The vehicle is being operated in a parade. 
(5)  The vehicle is being operated in an agricultural enterprise, including providing transportation to and from the principal place of the agricultural enterprise. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2000(3), § 1(g); Amend. of 1-12-2005; Amend. of 5-11-2010) 
Sec. 28-9. - Parking on or obstructing sidewalks and public right-of-way. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle on a sidewalk, bikeway, driveway, emergency vehicle access or where official signs prohibit, or otherwise obstruct the use of same by the public within the town. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place limbs, brush, etc. on any public parking area or town right-of-way that impedes vision or exceeds 42 inches in height. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to put debris on any other property or right-of-way other than from where the debris was originated, subject to the following exceptions: 
(1)  Flag lots: Debris for collection by the town shall be placed in the right-of-way abutting the adjacent lot with the longest street frontage. 
(2)  Lots accessible by alley: Debris for collection by the town shall be place in the nearest street right-of-way abutting the alley or lot. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect any pole, standard or tower, or make or dig any hole or make any excavations or dig into any street, sidewalk, alley, or any thoroughfare dedicated to public use or install any item over or under public right-of-way without first requesting and obtaining from the town public works directors permission to perform such work. It shall be unlawful for anyone to install or erect any apparatus or structure not limited to skateboard ramps or basketball goals, either permanent or portable, adjacent to or on street right-of-way. 
(e)  Right-of-way limitation. See section 26-1. 
(f)  No responsibility if removed. In the event of the town or utility companies need to make use of the street right-of-way, the town and/or utility companies shall be permitted to remove the structure and/or landscaping that exist within the street right-of-way and neither the town, utility company, or approved contractor shall be responsible for the repair or replacement of such landscaping, materials, or structures. 
(g)  Costs for removal. Non-approved landscaping, materials, or structures in the street right-of-way that are deemed to be a public safety hazard, impede traffic and hinder the use or maintenance of public utilities shall be removed at the homeowner's cost. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2000(3), § 1(h); Amend. of 1-12-2005; Amend. of 7-12-2005; Amend. of 12-13-2005(3); Amend. of 9-19-2017) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 26. 
Sec. 28-10. - Parking prohibitions. 
(a)  Parking on public owned property. Vehicular parking or obstruction on public right-of-way shall remain no longer than 72 hours (without prior approval from the town manager or his designee), so as not to impede any but not limited to the following town functions, right-of-way maintenance, grass cutting, meter reading. Excluding permitted parking, emergency and police vehicles. 
(b)  Parking prohibited at all times in designated places. When signs are placed, erected or installed giving notice of a "no parking zone," no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the areas or streets described in a schedule established and amended by the town council or town manager from time to time, and on file in the office of the town clerk. 
(c)  Towing of illegally parked vehicles. Any illegally parked vehicle may be towed. Any vehicle that has been towed for a parking violation is to be held until the towing fee and penalties related to all outstanding parking tickets and penalties owed to the city are paid in full or a bond is posted in the amount of the towing fee and all outstanding parking tickets and penalties. Payment of the towing fee and all outstanding parking tickets and penalties shall not constitute a waiver of a person's rights to contest the towing or the outstanding parking tickets and penalties. 
(d)  Obstructing fire hydrant. It shall be unlawful for any automobile, truck or vehicle of any kind to be parked within 15 feet of any fire hydrant. 
(e)  Handicapped parking. When signs are placed, erected or installed giving notice thereof, parking is prohibited at all times by all vehicles other than those designated as the vehicles of handicapped persons in areas properly designated as parking spaces for the handicapped. (Note: All required handicap signs and locations shall become compliance within six months from the date of this amended section.) 
(f)  No person shall obstruct an area within 15 feet of marked and designated emergency beach access points on the seaward side of the access. The schedule of emergency beach access points may be amended by the town council from time to time, and shall be on file in the office of the town clerk. 
(Ord. of 10-10-2000(3), § 1(i); Amend. of 6-10-2003; Amend. of 1-12-2005; Amend. of 7-12-2011; Amend. of 7-24-2014) 
Sec. 28-10.1. - Public parking on town right-of-way. 
(a)  Delivery trucks. In all residential zones, delivery trucks shall be required to make all efforts to avoid the impediment of traffic flow. Deliveries shall be limited to two hours. The time limit may be extended upon request and approval of the chief of police or his designee. When delivery trucks are required to stop on paved portion of the road, in order to meet delivery requirements, all safety precautions and devices to alert traffic shall be in place. 
(b)  Public parking on town right-of-way. Parking in designated areas recreational, town facility, and town maintenance parking areas shall be strictly enforced by time limits on signs, unless otherwise approved by the town manager, chief of police or his designee. 
(c)  Temporary residential right-of-way parking. Properly registered and operational personal property, owned or in the legal possession of the abutting property owner or guest, or legal tenant or guest of said property may be parked on the unpaved right-of-way so as not to create a traffic or safety issue, as determined by the chief of police or his designee. 
(d)  Construction site parking. Construction vehicles shall be restricted to onsite or right-of-way abutting property and any overflow parking shall be restricted to the right-of-way for less than 72 hours. At no point shall construction vehicles park on the pavement of the road or obstruct the road. Construction vehicles may not on park private property next to a job site without owner permission. 
(e)  All damage to right-of-way shall be the sole responsibility of the general contractor to correct before a certificate of occupancy shall be issued. No port-a-john, or required debris containers shall be allowed in the right-of-way. Construction vehicles shall not be permitted to park in part or in whole on pavement. 
(f)  Overnight parking. Overnight parking on town right-of-way is prohibited in the following locations: 
(1)  57th Place West. 
(2)  The 5700 block of West Dolphin Drive. 
(3)  The 5400 block of West Dolphin Drive. 
(g)  Parking in the public boat ramp parking lot located at Yacht Drive and 55th Street NE shall be limited to properly licensed vehicles with properly licensed and attached empty boat trailers not to exceed a period of 24 hours. 
(h)  Violation of the provisions of this section shall be punishable with a civil penalty in an amount set out in the fee schedule and maintained at town hall. 
(Amend. of 1-12-2005; Amend. of 7-12-2005; Amend. of 8-9-2005(2); Ord. of 8-8-2006; Amend. of 10-12-2010; Amend. of 7-13-2017; Amend. of 7-10-2018) 
Sec. 28-10.2. - Designated restricted parking areas. 
(a)  When signs are placed, erected or installed giving notice thereof, parking in designated spaces shall be restricted to Oak Island residents and property owners by display of a valid Oak Island resident or property owner parking decal issued by the Town. 
(b)  A schedule of locations for subsection (a) above as established, amended and deemed appropriate by the town council from time to time will be maintained and available for inspection at the police department and on file in the office of the town clerk. 
(c)  It shall constitute a violation of this chapter for any person to falsely represent himself as eligible for or to furnish any false information in an application to the Town in order to obtain an Oak Island resident or property owner parking decal. 
(d)  Oak Island resident or property owner parking decals may be obtained at the Oak Island Town Hall upon completion of an application and furnishing of proof of residency and property ownership. 
(e)  Enforcement shall be the duty of the police department. The purpose of this section is to: 
(1)  Reduce hazardous traffic conditions resulting from the use of streets within areas that have historically experienced high volume vehicular traffic with a shortage of parking spaces; 
(2)  Protect the subject areas from polluted air, excessive noise and trash and refuse caused by the entry of such vehicles; 
(3)  Protect the residents of those areas from unreasonable burdens in gaining access to their residences; 
(4)  Promote efficiency in the maintenance of those streets in a clean and safe condition; 
(5)  Preserve the value of the property in the subject areas; and 
(6)  Preserve the safety of children and other pedestrians and traffic safety, and the peace, good order, comfort, convenience and welfare of the inhabitants of the town. 
(f)  Violation of the provisions of this section shall be punishable with a civil penalty in an amount set out in the fee schedule and maintained at town hall. 
(Ord. of 5-13-2008; Amend. of 7-10-2018) 
Sec. 28-10.3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- An amendment adopted July 10, 2018, repealed § 28-10.3, which pertained to regulation of parking, vehicular and pedestrian traffic for street end of NE 2nd street and NW 2nd street and derived from an ordinance adopted Oct. 14, 2008. 
Sec. 28-10.4. - Regulation of parking, vehicular and pedestrian traffic for street-end of West Oak Island Drive. 
(a)  Oak Island Drive is a public street that ends immediately east of the eastern boundary of the mean high water mark of the Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway. Presently, the end of West Oak Island Drive is being used by the public to access the fishing "T" located on the Intracoastal Waterway. The end of West Oak Island Drive is presently unpaved and has no demarcated parking spaces. Regulating on-street parking, vehicular and pedestrian traffic in this area will promote the general health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(b)  In accordance with the authority granted under G.S. 160A-300, 160A-301 and section 22-6 of this Code, the town hereby adopts this section to implement the installation of three parking spaces located as close as possible to the Street-End's intersection with Yacht Drive over the current "rain garden" area or as close thereto as possible, with two of the spaces being standard parking space size and width and the remaining parking space being for handicapped parking and no additional parking. All other parking outside of these three parking spaces shall be prohibited within said street end. 
(Amend. of 7-21-2008; Amend. of 6-12-2012) 
Sec. 28-10.5. - Illegal parking. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to stop, stand, or park a vehicle: 
(1)  Whether attended or unattended upon any portion of the roadway so as to obstruct vehicle, pedestrian and/or bicycle traffic. 
(2)  So as to obstruct a curb ramp or curb cut for handicapped persons. 
(3)  In an area marked as a fire lane. 
(4)  On a street in front of a public or private driveway. 
(5)  Within an intersection. 
(6)  Upon any bridge. 
(7)  On a street median, unless the vehicle is disabled, and then only temporarily for a period not to exceed 24 hours. 
(8)  Within a public alley in such a manner that free movement of traffic is obstructed. 
(9)  In a marked parking space in a manner that its overall dimensions are not entirely within the parking space as marked. 
(b)  The prohibitions in this section shall not apply to emergency and public service vehicles whose operators are performing services for which they are responsible, nor do these prohibitions apply to vehicles belonging to persons under contract with the town to perform a public service. 
(Amend. of 9-10-2013) 
Sec. 28-11. - Speed limits. 
(a)  The speed limit for vehicular traffic upon the town-owned public streets within the corporate limits of the town shall be 25 m.p.h and 35 m.p.h. on Yacht Drive unless otherwise posted. 
(b)  The speed limit for vehicular traffic on NC 133 (Long Beach Road) from a point 0.1 mile south of the south end of the G.V. Barbee Bridge over the Intracoastal Waterway at 1.6 miles southwest of SR 1101 (Fish Factory Road) northeastward to SR 1101 (Fish Factory Road) in Oak Island shall be 45 m.p.h. 
(c)  The speed limit for vehicular traffic on SR 1105 (North Middleton Avenue/E.F. Middleton Boulevard) from SR 1190 (Oak Island Drive) to 0.474 miles north of SR 1190 in the Town of Oak Island, shall be 45 m.p.h. 
(d)  Violations of this section shall be a misdemeanor as provided by G.S. 14-4. 
(Ord. of 4-10-2001(5), § 1; Amend. of 1-12-2005; Amend. of 9-8-2009; Amend. of 5-10-2011; Amend. of 9-13-2016(2)) 
Sec. 28-12. - Penalty for violation of chapter. 
(a)  Except as may be otherwise provided for by state law or this chapter, any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be punished by proceedings as provided for in section 1-7. 
(b)  (1)  Notice to owner of 72-hour violation. If the chief of police or his designee determines that a vehicle is in violation of this chapter, then he or she shall give written notice of the violation found to the owner of the vehicle. Such notice shall direct the owner of the vehicle to remove the offending vehicle or otherwise rectify the violation within 14 days from the receipt of the notice by hand delivery or following receipt of the notice by registered mail. 
(2)  Notice of right to hearing. If the vehicle is towed at the request of the town chief of police or his designee, notice shall be given to the owner of the vehicle as set forth in N.C.G.S. 20-219.11 as the same may be amended from time to time. A copy of N.C.G.S. 20-219.11 is attached hereto and incorporated herein by reference. 
(3)  If the person served contends that such a vehicle is not in violation of the parking ordinance, abandoned or junk vehicles, he shall so notify the chief of police or his designee, in writing, of such contention within the 14-day notice period referred to in subsection (a) above. The failure of the person served to so notify the town shall be an admission that the vehicle is in violation of the parking ordinance, and abandoned or junk vehicle, and open storage of said vehicle shall be terminated in accordance with notice to the person served. However, notification to the town of such contention shall permit a representative of the town, if the latter so desires, to further inspect such vehicle within ten days of the town's receipt of such notification of contention. 
(4)  Whenever a police officer or authorized city employee or agent finds a motor vehicle that has been wrecked or disabled upon the public streets or ways of the town; or upon public property, or that may have been parked in violation of a town ordinance or state law, such individual may have the vehicle towed from the area. 
(5)  A police officer, in addition to this chapter, shall have a vehicle removed to a secure storage area during the enforcement of his duties. 
(6)  Towing of illegally parked vehicles. Any parked vehicle may be towed. Any vehicle that has been towed for parking violation is to be held until the towing fee and penalties related to all outstanding parking tickets and penalties owed to the city are paid in full or a bond is posted in the amount of the towing fee and all outstanding parking tickets and penalties. {Payment] shall not constitute a waiver of a person's rights to contest the towing or the outstanding parking tickets and penalties.
